The director managed to depict the sickness in a meaningful and truthful way: Anthony has its good moments where he laughs and he is full of life, but then, the more we go on, the more we see his condition getting worse and worse: he loses track of time and space, he swap events and people in his life, he is not able to think logically. The ending is heartbreaking, I was in tears.It is scary to see what aging can do to some people. This movie is like a lucid nightmare. It is slow paced, and lets the audience sink deeper and deeper into a malfunctioning brain. I am speechless, Florian Zeller partially restored my hope in modern cinema. I am happy to see that the mainstream market is still able to deliver good stories. The cast is small, and every single actor plays a specific role that fits in the plot. Everyone had the perfect amount of screen time. If I have to find one weakness, it would be some dialogues lines in a couple of dialogues with professional carers, that are not very believable. May this film be a lesson for all production companies: stop paying your attention exclusively to franchises and release more meaningful movies like "The Father". I am craving for them.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: It is a good movie, the way that is handled the mind in this movie is excellent. What to say about Anthony Hopkins, really good performance.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father is the 2020 directorial debut of French playwright Florian Zeller, with he co-wrote with Christopher Hampton based on his play Le Père. It received considerable praise on its release, not least for the central performance of Anthony Hopkins as the eponymous protagonist, which won him several awards including an Oscar for Best Actor. It was well deserved, but there's considerably more to the film than just Hopkins' acting.The Father is a heartbreakingly convincing portrayal of dementia, and the film's masterstroke lies in telling the story from the central character Anthony's point of view. Zeller achieves a remarkable insight into the mind of somebody with dementia, capturing the frustration, confusion, loneliness and fear of a man who is, literally, losing his mind. It's a superb piece of writing, with a narrative as fractured as the faculties of its protagonist who struggles to make sense of his life; dramatic coherence demands that the audience is allowed to do so, but only by assembling Anthony's snapshot, jumbled memories into a picture that he can no longer fully appreciate. The film is remarkable in capturing the unpleasant effects of dementia, remembering that it doesn't just cause benign memory loss, but can result in spite, anger, aggression, and deep emotional hurt to the victim's loved ones. As Anthony's condition worsens, so too does the confusion in the script: the audience is left uncertain as to whether Paul slapping Anthony really happens, or if he imagines it; only at the end do we learn that Anne really has moved to Paris, despite contradictory claims earlier in the film.Zeller and Hampton tease out the details of Anthony's past and present through his interaction with family members and carers, but obfuscate them by capturing Anthony's confused point of view in the shifting sets, cast changes and non-linear narrative. To convey Anthony's confusion, his daughter Anne is played by two different actresses, as is her husband Paul. Our understanding of those around Anthony changes from scene to scene and from actor to actor, proving as disorientating for the audience as it is for Anthony. This is reflected in the cinematography of Ben Smithard, whose camerawork manages to make the familiar seem suddenly cold and alien at times, and who uses point of view shots to make things less clear, not more. Ludovico Einaudi's subtle score helps, adding discordance at moments of confusion to create an unsettling air that reflects Anthony's state of mind.And the acting does ultimately contribute a great deal. Hopkins' naturalistically portrays Anthony's gradual deterioration over the course of the film, culminating in the much-praised scene of him crying for his mummy, and it is possibly a career best performance from a man with a very impressive career indeed. He's joined by Olivia Colman, who is very convincing as a loving daughter driven to her wit's end by her father's condition and his occasionally hurtful outbursts. She even imagines smothering him with a pillow at one point, whilst Anthony's needs also put strain on her marriage. These are painfully realistic depictions of what dementia can be like, in contrast to its occasional depiction in the arts and media as a sort of benign memory loss.The Father is hard to watch at times, but it is both worthwhile and rewarding, and as skilfully directed as it is written. It deserved all the plaudits lavished upon it, and it is to be hoped that Zeller's next feature film is just as impressive.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The best acting I've seen in a long time. The story is well done. Loved this film.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father does such a great job at displaying what it may be like to have mental illnesses such as dementia or Alzheimer's disease. It's pretty trippy and scary at the same time, and Anthony Hopkins gives such a believable performance. You really do feel like you're on the same ride as Anthony, all thanks to the great screenplay and directing.You also have Olivia Colman playing the daughter, Anne, and we can all agree that she can act on as high a level as Anthony Hopkins. Both give great performances, and it really adds to the realism.But, there is one major issue that I can't overlook. The story gets very pale about half way through. I had to take multiple breaks because it felt so long. There's a lot of repetition, which is what the director and screenwriters wanted, but it does get boring since the audience has already seen this exact scene already.All in all, The Father brings a sad and realistic story that can and will get boring depending on who's viewing it. But I think it's definitely worth experiencing because of how well the message was delivered, and how well produced it was.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
The father
2021
12A
Director: Florian Zeller
Starring: Anthony Hopkins, Olivia Colman, Mark Gatiss, Olivia Williams, Imogen Poots, Rufus Sewell etc
Overall rating 99/100The father is about an elderly man called Anthony (Anthony Hopkins) who refuses all assistance from his daughter as he ages. As he tries to make sense of his changing circumstances, he begins to doubt his loved ones, his own mind and even the fabric of his reality.Wow what a beautiful and cleverly constructed film that was very moving. The script was absolutely fantastic, some truly brilliant righting here. The performances were absolutely phenomenal, Olivia Colman was fantastic, but Anthony Hopkins was outstanding. His performance was powerful, moving and authentically told, showing the horrible effects dementia and Alzheimer's has on people, his Oscar was deserved. The soundtrack was cleverly linked with some scenes. The character of Anne (Olivia Colman) was a very likeable and strong character with how she handled her fathers declining health. The character conflict was great and understandable. The character development and depth was fantastic. Whilst also showing a fantastic balance to conflicting attitudes towards care homes and what's right for the different people involved. It was extremely cleverly constructed, it was like we were watching the film from the perspective of Anthony and jumbled plot represented his declining health, it was exceptionally well done. It also snuck in a bit of humour, the deep themes and emotional weight were very touching and hard to watch in places. The twists were well executed, and the ending was very moving.My only slight little nitpick would be that there was some unlikeable character decisions, but I sort of understood them.So overall, The Father is a cleverly constructed and beautiful film. That tells the story of someones battle with dementia so beautifully, authentically and cleverly, it was amazing to watch. It tackled the emotional themes well, and Olivia and Anthony did fantastic jobs. A must see film.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father is a thoroughly realistic and powerful depiction of dementia. Not only are the performances of Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman masterful, but the featured perspective is an unforgettable gem. This film is definitely an important must watch for teens and adults, and accurately earns it's truthful rewards.So not only is The Father a masterpiece; it's a total experience. What the film does is it grabs and places you in the perspective of a sufferer, meaning that the devastating story indeed relies on the realistic acting. This compelling tale is structured and gets very personal at times, but still manages to be a moving drama to be added to the must-watch list.So what else can you say? The Father is a wounding, heartbreaking and jaw-dropping masterpiece in which Anthony Hopkins delivers a breath-snatching performance. Now go ahead and experience this cleverly-made Alzheimer's drama.If you liked this review, check out the full review and other reviews at aussieboyreviews.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father is about an ailing, old man, Anthony, dealing with Alzheimer's. He is not a sweet, old man and portrayed as a victim, but rather, is cantankerous and rebellious. We see the struggle of his daughter, Anne, to take care of him. The film puts us in Anthony's mind, with jarring editing and story that distorts our sense of time. Like Anthony, we never have a true grasp on time - symbolically, Anthony is always losing his watch - and the order of events that are happening. We end with Anthony at a nursing home - or has he been there all along? - crying and powerless. The Father does a chilling job of putting us in the shoes of someone with Alzheimer's.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Cleverly made film dominated by a towering performance from Anthony Hopkins.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Out of the 5 films nominated for best film Oscar that I have seen (yet to see Nomadland, Minari and Mank) this is easily the best.If Chadwick Bozeman were alive, Anthony Hopkins would have been a sure shot winner. He is utterly brilliant, much better than his best known turn as Hannibal Lecter. The range of emotions on display will take your breath away. Utterly spellbinding.You would think that this would be a drama that would be purely driven by the strength of the performances. You would be slightly off the mark as the direction and the screenplay are top notch and will leave you unsettled, with their twists.Loved it. *My choice for best actor and best adapted screenplay Academy Awards*

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Only a few hours after watching this very interesting work I am here trying to find the right word to describe my emotional state during the viewing. We actually weren't only watching but we were participating. Not participating from our own volition but from the very intelligent plotting of this film. This film is about dementia, and dementia we get as an audience as we are so manipulated that we too experience the symptoms of dementia. We also go through the grief and despair of such situation. We get a few laughs to sooth the pain that is growing through the acting performance. The reality of this unreal world is atrocious as we can tell they can't be a very good ending...unless one can settle for a 'matter or fact'. But we all have our own particular take on what we would like the outcome to be. Are we kinder to...the horses?I'll have to say yes to spoilers ...

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: An old man and his daughter struggle with his dementia.This is a near-flawless film, and Anthony Hopkins is pitch perfect in every heartbreaking moment as the title character experiencing the pieces of his mind continually slipping through his fingers. After Silence of The Lambs, it's probably his best ever performance.The story is structured and edited in innovative ways to make us, the audience, feel as disorientated and confused as Hopkins, making us experience what he experiences in ways I don't think I've ever quite seen on film before (with the possible exception of Memento). It often feels closer to a horror film than anything else, but in a very quiet, sad, tender way that scares us by hitting so close to mundane, real world fears for ourselves and our loved ones, rather than through jump-scares, gore and violence.It's a very small story, impeccably played out by a very small cast, and perhaps some might find there's not enough surprises or a big enough payoff by the end. But it tells the story it has to tell perfectly well, and is by far the most powerful and compelling depiction of dementia ever put onscreen. I wouldn't be surprised if it turns out to be the best film I see this year, as well.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I won't elaborate here on Anthony Hopkins's superlative performance. It was superlative, but I've got nothing more to say about it that wasn't said already. Same is true of the rest of the cast - they were all amazing, but that's not my point. What I want to speak about is the cinematic brilliance of this entire experience (as it was much more than just a movie).Let us begin with the fact that the whole story is seen through the eyes of the father - which means that we the viewers are as lost as he is. We can't tell what's going on and it shakes us to the core.Now, let's speak about camera angles, in this movie the camera angles talks. They tell us things that Florian Zeller wants to tell us without saying them aloud. Think about the number of times you saw a horizontal picture of a wall with a door cracked open in the middle, but the camera didn't get any closer it was kept were we could see the wall at both sides of the door. Because Florian Zeller wants us to know there's a wider picture here - we simply don't get to see it since he, the director, doesn't want us to see it. And now let's try and count the number of long corridors with closed doors on both sides, usually dark corridors this is an old visual hint that our hero is moving on an unescapable rout to his destiny. No matter what he does - this story will end the same waySo you see, I love this movie because on top of a great performance and a great story - it speaks cinema. And now think of the fact that this is Florian Zeller's first movie. All he did so far is write brilliant plays the very first time he does cinema, he speaks its language as fluently as the very best. If that's not genius I don't know what is.It's dark and depressing but it's a masterpiece you simply have to see.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This is nothing like real life. I love Anthony Hopkins but this is a terrible portrayal of what living with someone with dementia is like. So disappointing.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Directed by Florian Zeller An old man named Anthony(Anthony Hopkins) suffers from an extreme case of Alzheimer's but refuses help from anyone and lives at home with his daughter Ann (Olivia Coleman) who does all she can to try to help him. However it's emotional struggle as her fathers health continues to deteriorate over the year and doesn't know what's left to do. Touching and heartwarming but rather depressing film. This this is a film that touches on a rather common real world issue that affects so many families it's a story that everyone can get behind even f you don't know anybody personally however it does has a certain impact on those who know somebody or themselves have succumb to Alzheimer. The movie deliverance shows how much of a struggle it is to dealing with, however not just from Ann's perspective but also from Anthony Hopkins whodelivers one of the best performances in his career. Hand down me of his most Memorable rolls fitting to go along side Hannibal Lecter & Pope Benedict It's not a straightforward story the film is all over the place multiple interpretations and different perspectives it does a great job keeping you off track and unaware what's fully going on. Someone's would probably say that that's a problem and it causes the point to where they're confused about what's going on. That's the point You can see that they tried to make you feel more what would be like to be in his position. Where everything is not as clear or an order now things to be misinterpreted or confused. It has more immerse immersion to the audience on that note. There's One scene the movie where Ann returns home but it's indicated to the point that he doesn't even fully recognize his own daughter and she literally looks like an entirely different person to him. Constantly their points were scenes play out but they play out varied. Olivia Colman does a marvelous job you feel her struggle, you want her to do her to try to do wants best what is the course not as simple as one wish it was. They're both in a helpless state each with in a struggle. The Father manages to captivated audience emotionally and keep you invested It was a magnificent performance highly warranted of its acclaim.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Usually watching a film is a bit of escapism and entertainment but sometimes it's hard hitting and close to home. This film is undoubtedly the latter.Both Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Coleman play their roles really well and convey the toughness of the situation.My only issue was, I understood what they were trying to do with the film, but there were parts of the plot that were hard to understand but maybe that was the point.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: British play turned into a sad two hours of tears and heartbreak. Would not recommend.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Great acting! Indeed an Oscar winner! He was so into the character.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Great acting. Indeed an Oscar winner. He is very into the character. Howey the story/characters are kind of confusing through out the movie.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The best film about the misfortune of aging since Umberto D by De Sica and Wild Strawberries by Bergman. Michael Haeneke's Amour does not even come close, despite its own merits & cast. The Father operates with a multifaceted, subtle and tricky point of view as soon as it sets the perspective pattern of a protagonist taken by dementia and / or Alzheimer's disease. The script doesn't sweeten anything. The dialog acts a message of ultimate understanding. In the Kammerspiele style, Anthony Hopkins demonstrates once again to be one of the greatest among actors. The crowd prefers it generally like Lecter, Richard Nixon or Titus Andronicus. I prefer him as C. S. Lewis and the steward of The Remains of the Day. This movie doesn't hide how dementia makes someone unrecognizable to their loved ones. It does trigger a storytelling trick (by the way, as its origin is a thetarical play, I imagine how it'd have been to frequently exchange same-role-performers on stage).

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: For middle-aged and above, we would not find the movie boring, though all the things just happen within a house, and with just a few actors.My mum has dimentia. My dad begins to have early stage of dimentia. Dimentia is my daily life, and I think is the intruder to lives of many. First we have to know it, before we can face it. I do not know if the writer has do some medical research on the illusion of dimentia patient or not. I hope he has. So, in a way, the movie helps us, as daughters and sons, to get to know our parents from thier point of view. It is simply educational.PS. It is a blessing that before my mum died, she can recognise all of us. And we will keep my dad recognising all of us too. To some extent, they can be trained.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
RATED 7/10
Language: EnglishSlow paced family drama told in non-linear way... other than this non-linear presentation, nothing impressive on this one...
some scenes are hard hitting and most are easily passable...
more art less entertainer....

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This was...just...damn.Some might say it's repetitive, has no real plot, or that the characters aren't very developed. I can't really disagree with any of that, but what this film also is is absolute bloody genius.Because rarely, if ever, will I see a film with a non-linear and intentionally confusing narrative and love it immediately without thinking about it more or watching it again, but this one managed it. For reasons I won't go into, however, because if you don't know what this is about, please keep it that way and just watch it.All you need to know is that the direction is flawless, the cinematography is great, especially for the limited setting, the structure is certainly unusual, but you'll understand why really quickly, the dialogue is amazing, Anthony bloody Hopkins, Olivia bloody Colman, and that it brought me to actual tears.The only thing I'll gripe about a little is the music, but aside from that, if everything I just said isn't enough to convince you to watch this, then...well, I don't know what to say other than you're just...wrong.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: An exceptional and ingenious film that impressed me. An unusual and courageous move to follow the plot of the film from the perspective of an old, senile and demented man, but I really liked the end product. It looks like a show because we learn almost everything from dialogues that don't always make sense and because "nothing happens" in the film, something I don't like at all, but here I really liked it. Interestingly, the lead role was written exclusively for Anthony Hopkins because the main character and he have the same name and even share the same birthday. Hopkins is the soul and heart of this film as everything revolves around it. He goes through several different phases and moods, and he delivered everything neatly and we got one of the best male roles last year, but also in the entire career of the great Sir Anthony Hopkins, which says a lot about the quality. The supporting roles are at a high level because everyone does their part the way they should or the way the film demands, for the purpose of the action and the role. A movie that holds your attention all the time and is by no means a feel good movie or a movie to relax. I hope it finds his audience and gets some award because this movie deserves it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: ....but somewhat depressing for the over 80 viewers who may suffer from forgetfulness.Sir Anthony Hopkins gives an extraordinary performance, flanked by the great Olivia Colman - both nominated for Oscars. The film is also Oscar nominated for best picture.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Now this is what I would call the Best Picture of 2020 and Anthony Hopkins surely deserved his Oscar for such a complex character he portrayed.As I was watching the movie, it was as if I was in Anthony's head, trying to figure out heads and tails of everything that was going on: who am I, where am I, what's my story, who are the people around me, is it my apartment, what happened ten minutes ago, and finally, is it real at all? The cinematography is fantastic, how the transitions are made up into one big loop of events that round up to make sense but in the end nothing really makes sense when you're losing your memory to a weary old mind.I guess it will take multiple watches for me to look out for all of the details I missed to make a picture to at least seem whole but as of now The Father is a perfect representation of what's really happening inside the head of an old sick man and Sir Anthony played his part gracefully and was very touching. So did Olivia Colman and all the rest of the cast.Overall I feel like there's so much left for me to discover in this movie and this is literally the best thing about the art of cinema: that it puts a seed of wisdom or a thought into your brain and let it blossom naturally, and, when the movie is as great as this one is, with every new rewatch it will give your tree of thoughts more and more branches, colors and beauty.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: We don't just lose our memories when our brains deteriorate. Sometimes memories are corrupted; misplaced. Sometimes they appear to get repeated. In any case, we lose our ability to perceive the world - and our very lives - as we once did.We can discuss the existential implication of the way our minds operate another time (I have a friend who believes the human brain could be rewired to perceive time nonlinearly but still be considered functional, though I would have some questions on logistics and semantics there). I'm only here to tell you about The Father, one of the best films of this year's #KeepingUpWithTheOscars marathon and one of the most moving portrayals of dementia since Haneke's Amour (2012). Notably, this one lets us see things from the dementia patient's point of view.This is the first film Florian Zeller has directed, although it is based on a similarly named stage play of his. Sometimes (as with Ma Rainey's Black Bottom, another multi-category Oscar nominee, from the same playwright as 2016's Fences), this can be almost too obvious; the scenery rarely changes and not much "happens", per se.But The Father has nightmarish sequences worthy of Kaufman's I'm Thinking of Ending Things. I don't know how some of these scenes must have looked on a live stage, but they might've made me forget I was watching real people perform with little-to-no magic involved. It's hard for any of us to remember going to live shows in general, but you know what I mean.Anthony Hopkins gives what's possibly his finest performance since Hannibal Lecter, in the role of a British geezer named Anthony (perhaps indicating that Hopkins himself is beginning to muse on these things). But instead of a menacing force of evil, this is a character we all recognize too well from real life; a stubborn old goat who's certain he doesn't need any help, even as he begins to lose track of his recent memories, and soon also distant ones.Time is played around with in other ways throughout the film, but I dare not reveal too much. I can tell you that Anthony's daughter, played by the always-phenomenal Olivia Colman, begins to appear to him with different faces, different life plans, and even different husbands. Sometimes he doesn't remember the faces he's shown; sometimes he remembers them from the wrong places. The plot makes us wonder if someone is messing with him; gaslighting him until he must be dumped in a nursing home to live out his deterioration in solitude.People often wonder, what's even the point of a film like The Father? These days especially, surely escapist entertainment or something hopeful is what we need? This, to me, indicates a narrow understanding of film, presuming that filmmakers must never make films for themselves; that their duty is always to entertain, instead of translating their thoughts and worries into an artistic expression.Films like that aren't always fun, I agree. But The Father is legitimately powerful and clever in its presentation - and for some of us (especially if we're currently going through something eerily similar to what's being explored), watching a movie like it is a reminder that there are people out there who understand. It's not an Avengers sequel, but I assure you those are still around.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: A very impressive feature length directorial debut by Florian Zeller who also co-wrote this. It's about a man experiencing the final decline of Alzheimer's created with a clever, disorienting point of view causing the viewer to sometimes have the same confusion as the father in the title. Anthony Hopkins gives a very memorable performance, though I kind of wish it weren't, and the rest of the cast is fine, but this is Hopkins' show and it is an extremely depressing one. Also outstanding was the production design that is also clever. This is a good movie, but I had to immediately do something else as this left me far too sad. The actor, director and editor have made probably created one of the few films that gives us a feel of this terrible condition.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony (Anthony Hopkins) has Dementia and cannot understand why things are not the same and becomes confused all the time. He gets rid of Caretakers because he doesn't like them. His daughter Anne (Olivia Colman) takes care of him, but needs to have him put into a home where she can live her life and he will be, hopefully, happy there.In the beginning we believe everything we see and hear according to Anthony's way of seeing things. Takes a few minutes for us to realize there are things we cannot really see or hear. Because Mr. Hopkins is what he is even when in Anthony's character, who has Dementia, the way he sees and says things we believe him. After a while we realize our mistake and we have to keep fighting this belief.Notables: Rufus Sewell as Paul, Anne's former husband who Anthony sees as real and, who tells Paul that Anne will move to Paris to be with another man and Paul tells Anthony that he, knows nothing about Paris and that Anthony is living in Paul's flat, but Anthony still believes he is in his own flat; Mark Gatiss as Bill, Anne's current husband, who asks Anthony how long will he (Anthony) live off Anne; and later Bill tells Anne that Anthony should be in a home for others to care for him; Imogene Poots as Laura, the only Caretaker Anthony likes and misses when she is no longer there and Anthony sees another woman who calls herself that Laura; Olivia Williams as Catherine, as the Nurse at the Nursing Home, who simulates Anthony's mother in the way she soothes Anthony, And there is a scene where Olivia Williams plays Anthony's daughter Anne, and Anthony does not recognize the difference. See? Will you notice?Some of the scenes are confusing, but all will straighten out in time. I am still not sure if Anne is actually married to Bill or not. I do kind of wish Mr. Hopkin's character was not named Anthony for obvious reasons.This is very sad, tragic, heart wrenching and we are at a loss like Anthony because no matter what Caretakers do, it's really not enough. As we watch this, we not only see a confused Anthony and his daughter Anne who fights back tears all the time, we think of the many families out there who have the same or similar problems with a loved family member and feel helpless.Anthony Hopkins received the Oscar for Best Actor Award for this story. For a while I thought that almost any actor could perform the job as good as anyone else, but I was wrong. This time Anthony Hopkins brought something else to the story - a kind of new dimension - and I felt as though he was my family member and I was as helpless as we saw Anne helplessly deal with everything.This was probably the best performance ever by Mr. Anthony Hopkins. Multiple Kudos. (10/10)Violence: No.Sex: No.Nudity: No.Humor: Kinda. There are some good lines by Mr. Hopkins as Anthony.Language: Yes, but only 2-times.Rating: A.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Hopkins is a brilliant actor. His performance might have worked very well for a stage performance. Here it comes across as overacting.And let's face it, while it might have seemed like a good idea in 2020 to make a movie about a confused old man, now we have Biden on TV each day.Give the Ocsar to Sir Anthony, but not one for the movie.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The movie is just incredible, first, the cinematography is beautiful, and the movie looks gorgeous, the acting is just insanely great, Anthony Hopkins is at his best here, giving a truly Oscar winning performance, you can fell his confusedness, you can really enjoy the good and happy moments he has with his love ones, but also the moments of sadness and loneliness too. And that's not all, Olivia Colman is also great, and you can feel how fragile the situation is to her in every scene, how challenging it is, and how she just loves Anthony. Imogen Poots has a bit of screen time too, and she is also pretty good, Mark Gatiss as always as well. Anyways, the cast is great.But probably what makes this movie different from everything I have ever seem is the structure of the story itself, the constant changing of scenarios, and actors or even characters suddenly, with often conflicting information been given by more than one character, puts you in Anthony's shoes, and see how just helpless a person on that situation feels like, and how insanely confusing everything is.The mix of this perfect story structure, with top notch performances, makes this movie just an immersive and breathtaking experience from start to finish. I loved it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I watched this movie as soon as I heard it received Oscar. The movie is really good. It makes us realize how old people suffers but we even don't realize. We try to get rid of them though we know, we are hurting their feeling. So cruel! It is even more difficult for a person having demensia. Anthony Hopkins did a amazing job and it is as good as'' The silence of the lambs''.Anyone may finds this movie a bit boring as it is kind of realistic movie about elderly aged person situations, feelings. But,for acting heads down, can't compliant.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: It portrays what getting old is like and how it feels.This movie is wonderful, the script and the direction puts you in the place of the protagonist and you feel his emotions without even reaching that age, it is sad to see that one day we will reach that age and unfortunately we will feel unloved and abandoned. Everything is very good, the performances, the script, the production design, the photography, the music and absolutely everything.It seems to me a magnificent film, with a story that takes time to understand but in the end everything makes sense and with a very valuable lesson about being older and feeling lonely.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony, 80 years old, rejects all the caregivers his daughter, Anne, hires to help him, leading her to exhaustion.There are films that are good, others that are really good, and then there is a very restricted selection where The Father is in.Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman are two colossus, of those who do not need awards to be recognized.The aspect of continuity in this film is at a level that I don't remember seeing in a long time, being almost perfect from start to finish.The cinematography is really smart, confusing everything and everyone, with transitions between scenarios and characters that leave the viewer with doubt and not knowing what to believe.It's real, emotional, rational, in the midst of the irrationality of dementia, it's a desolate chaos that plants doubt and suspicion, and exposes the vulnerability and the absence, while present, of a person who is lost between memories and suffering.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: We are truly spoiled for choice at this years Oscars, especially in the Best Actor Category.In delivering their career-best performances in Ma Rainey's Black Bottom and the Father, Chadwick Boseman and Anthony Hopkins are in my opinion, deadlocked as favourites for the Oscar.In the Father, Anthony Hopkins leaves you spellbound as a geriatric father of two slowly devolving into advanced stages of dementia.The non-linear narration and side characters coming thick and fast caused some confusion in the beginning, but the director resolves all the threads towards the end and in turn, brilliantly communicates the confusion and hysteria that must be going through the mind of dementia patients.Hopkins certainly deserves the Best Actor Oscar for this, clearly his career-best performance.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This movie made me sad, made me for a short while experience the life lived by family members of those suffering from dementia. The wonderful performances by these actors and actresses can never be forgotten, great directing to a great cast with powerful dialogues that ring in your head after the movie is over. The movie does a good job of making you scared for a bit and later switches you back to sadness mode. I really did enjoy this movie and I highly recommend it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
The Father is a great movie. Anthony Hopkins gives one of his best performances as an elderly father who is unlikable at times, but also empathetic and relatable too. The film is simple, but keeps you engaged the whole time and doesn't outstay its welcome due to its 90 minute runtime.It's shot nicely, the supporting actors give very good performances too, and
you really feel for the characters. Of all the Best Picture 2021 nominations, this might be the best one for me. Sure it's not the most original story ever, but it's the execution that matters the most, and by the end it hit me harder than expected. I really connected with it.8/10

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father is a devastating film. One man's descent into dementia becomes a gutting reminder of your own mortality. The heartbreak of watching Anthony's mind, and with it his relationships, unravel is almost unbearable at times. The film reminded me of the famous Gerard Manley Hopkins poem Spring and Fall, in which the poet begins by asking a young child, "Margaret are you grieving, Over Goldengrove unleaving?" He goes on to say: "Now no matter, child, the name; Sorrow's springs are the same," and concludes with the lines, "It is the blight man was born for, It is Margaret you mourn for." By the end of The Father, I was a blubbering mess, mourning as much for Anthony as for myself.Read the full review on Film Companion.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: It just makes me want to give anyone with Alzheimer's a hug and tell them it's going to be okay. An incredibly insightful and relevant film into such a misunderstood and cruel disease. Watch it and figure out why the elderly deserve so much respect. Anthony Hopkins was perfect for the role, showing that he's still at the top of his game after all these yearsHopefully we'll find a way to end this horrible disease one day.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Used to work as a live-in carer for years. I am glad this story goes out and hope more people will understand better all three sides; the elderly Individual, the family and the caretaker. Thank you.Brilliant movie. Excellent acting- but obviously with the greatest actors it wasn't a surprise.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
Dementia.
Spoiler, this may not end well, but that's not the point.In Florian Zeller's "The Father", a one room play turned expertly into a gripping two hours of cinema, the blubbery heartbreak or the cheerleadery miracle usually reserved for this genre are absent. Instead we are tricked into inhabiting Anthony Hopkin's wandering mind. And it is an unsettling, frightful, place, where surroundings shift, names change, events may or may not happen, bluster resides, and paranoia reigns. Perspective is thrown out the window. Yet each vignette seems real enough to believe. The hopeful ones are easy to cling to. The harsh ones are shattering.As his taxed daughter, her father's lone connection to a world that is slowly leaving him, Olivia Colman makes this a two actor tour de force. Her conflict, to live for herself or offer selfless support, is an anvil sized weight on both of their minds. Yet it is unclear which direction she favours, if in fact she favours any at all. Sprinkled with just enough amusing asides - the obsessive infatuation with and reliance on a watch for instance - there is enough levity for Hopkins to stretch like he's never stretched before. The two leads are fabulous on screen.Just as the play starts to roll, it changes gears. The flat is different. The characters too. A promised plan is no longer on the table. What is this? Who are they? Where are we? What is reality? And who's reality is it? Infuriating, but cleverly diabolical, these curve balls are subtle enough not to jar, but they do build to a powerful crescendo. It is a bit of an accomplishment to deliver a series of deliberately confusing acts without losing the audience to frustration. Oh there is frustration, but that is part of the experience. This is not an easy view, but a worthwhile one.hipCRANK

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: We often hear that health is the most important thing. The older we get, the more we realize that as our backs start to feel stiff in the morning or our knees begin to ache from driving. Mental health is different because you might feel that you are in tip-top shape while in reality, those around you have been trying to cope with your symptoms for a long time. The Father is a story of an old man who is stubborn about moving to an elderly home and instead chooses to live in his daughter's flat. Or does the daughter live in his flat?He isn't quite sure where he actually lives as each day the surroundings seem to change without his consent. Despite that, he is going about his business as if everything is normal while in reality it's far from that and his daughter is the one who is heartbroken because her father is not in his right mind.It's obvious that the events are tragic but because of how Anthony acts and the way in which the film presents his "adventures", it feels ok to laugh. As a matter of fact, Hopkins wants you to laugh up until a certain point where both his acting and the film's mood signify that things have become quite serious. "Where has all my life gone?" - he says and at that instant, you can't help but feel a certain pain in your heart. What's more, your head will begin to spin in an attempt to connect the small pieces to the big picture.We all know that Sir Anthony Hopkins is a Titan of acting but he seemingly disappeared during the last decade. Turns out he has been saving up his acting for the right role and this outstanding performance puts him right next to Riz Ahmed in the lead to win the Oscar. Oh, and Olivia Colman managed to surprise once again. Like many of Sir Anthony's movies, this one is filled both intelligence and profound depth which makes you want to watch it more than once. The tricky part is that the emotions of the first experience are not so easy to get over.Movies.shmovies on Instagram for movie and tv revirws

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony Hopkins plays a man suffering from dementia and having to deal with his daughter Anne played brilliantly by Olivia Colman caring for him. Hopkins is equally brilliant. You feel his sense of loses his mind and not knowing what is real and what is not. The film is so beautifully written and constructed. The film is so well acted by Colman and Hopkins. At times it is hard to watch and you really feel for the characters. I think it is one of best films you can see right now. I can see why it got so many Oscar nominations. I would not be surprised if Hopkins and Colman both win. It is a deeply moving film that will stay with you for a long time.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Move over "Suspiria," "The Conjuring" and "Hereditary" - there's a new film that has claimed the title as the scariest movie of the past decade. It's not demons, witches or serial killers that make this new movie scary; it's something that has affected our loved ones and may affect us in the future: dementia."The Father" is a triumphant directorial debut by Florian Zeller, who puts us within the deteriorating mental state of our main character, Anthony. We experience his confusion as if it were our own. The film also takes on the perspective of the caretakers who are left helpless as they try to aid Anthony in making sense of a world he cannot recognize anymore.Zeller's play "The Father" debuted in Paris in 2012 to rapturous reviews. Its success spurred an acclaimed Broadway run with Frank Langella winning a Tony award for his performance. Now Zeller, with the help of esteemed screenwriter Christopher Hampton, has taken his stage play to the screen.At the center of the film playing the character of Anthony is veteran actor Anthony Hopkins (Zeller was so adamant about getting Hopkins for the role that he renamed the character specifically for him).With a nearly 60-year career in the rearview, including notable roles as Hannibal Lecter in "The Silence of the Lambs" and Richard Nixon in Oliver Stone's aptly named "Nixon," Hopkins' performance here may be his very best. He is charismatic, fierce and vulnerable, sometimes all at the same time.If not for Chadwick Boseman's untimely death and larger-than-life performance in "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom," Hopkins would be the undisputed favorite to win his second Oscar this year.The world we see is through Anthony's eyes. Initially, his world is quiet and still, often filled with days listening to classical music in his luxurious London flat and taking walks in the nearby park. After a while, however, things slowly start to come apart. He's displacing items more regularly, days are getting harder to separate and conversational details are getting lost in the shuffle.One day, his daughter Anne (Olivia Colman) tells him she's leaving London to go live in Paris with her new significant other. Feeling he's being abandoned, Anthony is hurt by his daughter's decision. The next morning, however, Anthony is still in his flat and has no recollection of Paris.Maybe that conversation happened a long time ago or never happened at all. Maybe this isn't Anthony's flat - maybe it's Anne's and she's taken him in to stay with her. Maybe she has a husband here named James (or is it Paul?) and she's now being played by a different actress than before.Like a Charlie Kaufman or Christopher Nolan film, Zeller plays with time and setting to tell his story. Conversations are repeated several times over from different perspectives, adding another level to the complex task of discerning what is fact and what is fiction.Anthony's physical surroundings seem to be rearranging at impossible speeds and the chronology of events is becoming increasingly muddled. Production designer Peter Francis and editor Yorgos Lamprinos deserve immense credit for their work here as their craftsmanship helps tell a complicated story.The confusion and frustration that Anthony feels are equally placed onto us as we are never sure what is happening and what order it is happening in. It's like watching a balloon being inflated and waiting for it to pop, yet it never does as your anxiety keeps building.It's a terrifying and heartbreaking process to watch as Anthony's mood begins to darken. He never knows what is going to come next and what has just happened. He's left in a perpetual state of fright and feels that everyone is out to get him.Those around him are equally as confused and scared as he is. Anne doesn't know what to do with her father and is fighting a losing battle of keeping an optimistic look at things. Colman, a recent Oscar winner for her role in "The Favourite," acts somewhat as our guide through this mess. Imogen Poots, Olivia Williams, Mark Gatiss and Rufus Sewell all play well-cast supporting roles.Like "Schindler's List" and "Requiem for a Dream," "The Father" is a superb film that you will only want to watch once. Its subject matter may hit too close to home for some viewers or be an introduction for others. No matter your familiarity, the film's take on dementia and the toll it places on everyone involved is so incredibly well done that it demands to be seen.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
POSITIVES:1) Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman both deliver the best performances of their career in my opinion. Breathtakingly amazing. Hopkins deserved the Oscar
2) The way the film makes the setting, mainly the flat, seem like its own character was extremely well done. I found the film becomes claustrophobic because of how much the flat becomes like a prison. Anthony is always looking at the window but never once do we see him go outside
3) The way the film plays with time and narrative is genius. As an audience member we feel like we are the ones slowly losing our minds, just like Anthony. The way scenes loop back round on each other and get seen from slightly different perspectives really kept me engaged
4) The emotion of the film was incredibly impactful to me, partly because I have experienced this to a certain extent in my family, but also because the film and the performances are masterfulNEGATIVES:1) Anthony became difficult to sympathise with at times when he was being rude, belittling or even hostile towards his daughter and his carer. I understand that this probably adds to the realism of the film, but as a character it made me find Anthony too frustrating at times
2) I wish there was just 10 minutes at the end where we went back and saw the film objectively / through Anne's eyes. I left the film still confused about which events actually happened and which didn't, in what order things were meant to have happened, was Paul really rude and aggressive towards Anthony or was all that made up?

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony is great as always. He is losing the grasp on reality is very well portrayed. You go through the dementia along with him. Her daughter, fragile yet charming displays a range of emotions going through this tough time. Its not only the ill who goes through the illness the one taking care also gets affected and tested. You will be left too emotional at the end of this.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony Hopkins's one man show. Belongs on the stage. As a movie rather boring.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I'm a big fan of Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman, so I was really looking forward to this one after it got rave reviews out of Sundance. This film is based on a stage play, and centers around a woman in a relationship who visits her aging father, who is beginning to show signs of dementia, in London due to concerns that he can no longer take care of herself. Narratively, it's not always as memorable as one would hope, but the strong performances and careful direction carry the film home at the end of the day and overall craft something certainly worth watching.Anthony Hopkins is undoubtedly terrific here. He is able to convey both frailty yet genuine shock and empathy, while trying to better understand those around him that even he regularly connects with. Colman's performance is compassionate yet multi-layered, conveying clear emotional depth. The film's aesthetic is simple, modest and unpretentious, yet it manages to skillfully and quietly play a role within the film as a whole by adding to an atmosphere of confusion about what is real and what is not real due to Hopkins' character's dementia. The screenplay is generally well-written, but the dialogue is not quite as sharp or powerful as one would hope. Despite a fleeting running time, the film is leisurely paced, which is fine because it allows viewers the ability to take in the details of the characters' interpersonal relations. Yet while very moving in parts, the story doesn't quite build up to a true emotional crescendo that one would expect from a powerful, character-driven drama. That said, the acting combined with a thoughtful tone of generally subdued reverence makes the film very worthwhile viewing. 7.5/10

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Movie was done From dementia patients perspective of view ,it's was way correct from it as dementia patients tends to RMB the lines but forgot who's the person say it. But it's way wrong to put in the movie that was dull due to its repeatedly lines and Scene.luckily the performance by all cast was superb.that's many movie about dementia was sad and touching just 10min way better than this movie.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I guess the titel says it all. One thing I learned, though, is that Olivia Colman did not put up any kind of act when she did the Queen. Apparently that is how she looks and talks, because she looked and sounded identical in The Father as to her appearance in the Queen.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: If you've ever known anyone with Alzheimer's, this film and it's brilliant deconstruction of time and place do an incredible job of capturing the confusion and disorientation of dementia. It's so well written and masterfully laid out, you won't understand all the fragments yourself at first. Brilliantly takes the viewer into that frightening and upsetting experience. And what can I say about Anthony Hopkins performance? He's been turning in one great performance after another for decades, and this is one of his best ever. Not an easy film, but well worth the watch.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This film will tug at your heart strings. Anthony Hopkins takes us on a ride that many of us will deal with someday, dementia. With every emotion he acts out you feel that emotion deep in your soul. After the movie it took awhile for myself to disengage from it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony Hopkins delivered one of his greatest performances. I would have enjoyed the movie more, if it wasn't that depressing and sad.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony Hopkins performance in this film is so unbelievably, amazingly heartbreaking.Florian Zeller tells a story focused around dementia that is super well edited and will take you on a wild, jarring, ride that's complimented beautifully with a very serene and emotional score.I did feel like for an hour and a half runtime it was a bit slow, but I was in for the ride and the pacing never bothered me at all. This film really messes around with time, reality, and perception in such a fascinating, confusing and heartbreaking way that seemed really special and unique.It's definitely worth the watch especially for Hopkins breathtaking performance alone.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This movie is like a maze, we're taken on a journey through Tony's mind. Tony's who suffers from dementia cannot recognize the people around him. Zeller manages to manipulates the audience to experienced the same thing, unable to fully understand what's going on and never know who to trust thus making this movie a bit terrifying.While the frequent changes of perspective can cause quite a confusion, what's happening throughout with the apartment design is cunning and subtle. Little changes to major changes can be seen throughout the movie, from tiles to cabinet pattern to the clothing and even plastic bag, it was really neat. Different color palettes and different layouts were use to tell whose character perspective are we looking at.Hopkins performance was off the roof, he was charismatic and playful but sometimes cruel. Definitely one of his best performance. To sum it up this movie was horrifying, compelling and confusing, I had a great time.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The movie The father by Director Florian Zeller is about what aging does to a loving relationship between a father Anthony (actor Anthony Hopkins) and a caring daughter Anne (actress Olivia Colman) . Early signs of dementia and Anthony sitting alone in his chair with vivid memories of his two daughters , Anne who is alive and Lucy who died years back are depicted very well. Coming in and out of past into the present oblivious to who is around him, Anthony interacts with guests in his usual charming manner. Anne as a patient and caring daughter who shares with her dad the unhappiness of losing her only sibling is authentic. Anne listens to her father talking proudly about artistic talents of Lucy who is long gone but father makes it sound like Lucy is alive . Screenplay by Florian Zeller and Christopher Hampton is excellent. Antony Hopkins as the father is great. Loved the scenes when Anthony is trying to get up from his chair, scenes where he patiently tries again and again to slide his arms into sleeve of sweater while Anne watches father struggle with simple acts taken for granted , scene while driving Anne gently puts her hand on dad's hand and he avoids the touch. Olivia Colman is extremely talented and was adored in the movie The favourite . Anthony Hopkins , great in movies like Silence of the Lambs and The Two Popes , is definitely perfect as The father. Oscar worthy Direction, screenplay, editing. Oscar worthy acting by Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman. My first movie on the big screen after 365 days.97minutes of best emotional display.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Just look into the film only because Anthony Hopkins won the Best Actor award at Oscar 2021, but along with his performance the film provides something new. Already went through lot of movies dealing with the subject, 'dementia' or some sort of mental problems but this one found a different path of story telling. A new way of narrative technique were we just fell along with Anthony and the surprises on his way and the revelations that he is undergone. He was exceptional in his role and that is unquestionable because we saw the shade in the well-known Hannibal Lector. This one is completely opposite to it because the physicality is even less here than in The Silence of Lambs. Here he is an octogenarian, a man struggling with dementia. Hopkins wonderfully carried that character. Not but the least Olivia Colman's Anne was also superb. Hats off to the production designer and the Editor too.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I started watching the film not knowing what to expect. Then, throughout the film, it was twists and turns, one after the other... so beautifully and elegantly done. Anthony Hopkins was superb, an absolute masterpiece of excellent acting. Just amazing...BTW, the other actors were excellent - Olivia Colman was super, Mark Gatiss, as usual, excellent, the nurse, the carer, the husband... all wonderfully portrayed. Watch it again??? Yes, definitely!Highly recommended - and the final scene was powerful and emotional.!WoW!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
Dementia is distressing
The Script is cleverly woven to show us what its like to live through dementia from the view of the victim. Anthony Hopkins does a wonderful job of portraying the victim. The change of principle characters is confusing but imagine how upsetting it is for someone actually living through it.The sound is ok
The Photography is ok
The Acting is GoodIts worth a watch 👍

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
TIFF 2020 12
The Father
Base on the stage play by the same name, director Florian Zeller adapts his own play to the big screen, telling the story of Anthony (Sir Anthony Hopkins), an elderly man dealing with severe case of Alzheimer disease with some stages of dementia and his daughter Anne (Olivia Colman) who tries her best to take care of her father.With the help of an unconventional script and some illusion-inducing cinematic techniques, we are seeing the most parts of the film from Anthony's viewpoint. Some scenes repeats themselves with completely another character replaced, some elements form the set are altered or entirely disappeared, even the house Anthony is living in may change completely and through these modifications we get to experience the dementia that is affecting Anthony (or many real life people for that matter) and his sense of perception.This film makes brilliant use of every part and aspect to tell its story in the most compelling and intriguing way possible. Both performances by Hopkins and Colman are phenomenal and writer/director Zeller knows exactly what he wants to do and does it with eagerness and care. It is not certainly enjoyable per se, but it is surely thought-provoking and memorable.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: "The Father" blew me away! Anthony Hopkins is getting all manner of accolades for his performance and deservedly so, but Olivia Colman is brilliant too.The film plays out from the point of view of the man with Alzheimer's. Consequently, the storyline is hallucinatory, disjointed, confusing, filled with internal contradictions, and makes dizzying leaps in time. All that works to the movie's advantage as it shows us how that loathsome disease will turn a once-vital man into a desiccated husk of his former self.Having witnessed the ravages of Alzheimer's as it destroyed two people I loved, I found a lot to relate to in "The Father." One example is the fantasy segment in which Ann imagines herself choking the life out of the old man. She has these thoughts not out of malice or resentment, but because she wishes to end her father's suffering, as well as her own.One issue the film does not address is finances. The characters are well off enough that when Ann makes the heartbreaking decision to put her father in a nursing home, he gets a private room in a comfortable-looking facility with a nurse who gives him one-on-one attention.Having once held a driving job for a pharmacy, I delivered to a lot of nursing homes. Many of them stank of urine and feces, crammed several patients into a room, and were severely understaffed so that one-on-one care was impossible. I would be interested in someday seeing a film about Alzheimer's in which the victim and his loved ones are working-class or poor.Having seen only a handful of movies from the Year of Covid, I can't say for sure that "The Father" is the best film of 2020. It is, however, the best one I've seen. This is nothing to watch if you're looking for escapist entertainment; but if you want a film for the ages, you've found it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Wow wow Anthony Hopkins and the director did incredible work , the story is very simple but the way they show you how the mind tricks the old, yes the movie is emotional but it is worth every minute .

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: One of my all time favorite movies is Charlie Kaufman's Synecdoche, New York which narrates the ever deteriorating world around a playwright bordering on reality and insanity. And Florian Zeller's The Father is the closest I've seen that captures the insanity of the decaying mind, but told through the apparatus of a very real and universal issue.The movie was unsettling from start to finish... in the best way possible. It's one that shows the unstable world around the aging Anthony, but with the underlying vigilance that what's "wrong" is not necessarily the world around him. And the horror of one's rationality clinging on to his very last bit of sanity is shown in the most surprisingly human way possible, and it's what makes The Father one of the finest movies of the year.Special credits to stars Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman, who undoubtedly make the movie as every bit emotional and human. And Hopkins' performance in this movie is by far my favorite of the year. Overall, a very intense yet rewarding viewing experience that no one should miss out on. Do yourselves a favor and check it out!!!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Oh my God!!!! I really dont have words to explain this movie. I really live the way in which we are also passing through the same disease from which Anthony is passing through. I really was so much curious to know what happens in end so that I know what was happening in this whole movie. And in last scene after watching it,I like kind of felt the numbness of my life and and saw it very closely. The way Anthony acts Oh God it was toooooo perfect. I can watch this movie again and again seriously. I do got the movie but for 100% complete satisfaction I watched the explanation of this movie and after watching it I love this movie even more.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This movie is mind-blowing. Not only does it give you the perspective of a mind that has devolved into dementia, it creatively immerses you in their moment-to-moment thoughts and experiences through the repeating confusing scenes, changing context, strange faces, disappearing furniture, etc. Now who could convincingly portray an old man who has lost his mind through an acting performance that showcases the opposite of dementia? None other than Sir Anthony Hopkins! Here, we have this veteran actor at 82 years old who could very well be a victim of dementia himself at that ripe old age. Instead, he is firing at all cylinders, giving us this heartwarming performance of a lifetime making us convinced that he really has dementia, but the act of doing so just proves he is at the top of his game with elite-level acting. Who would've thought that after 30 years of his legendary Hannibal Lecter, he would top himself with this one? I look forward to more Anthony Hopkins films to come!

Title: THE FATHER

If you want to see a better movie of this kind watch a moment to remember or the judge, where these movies actually has a much better emotional story with characters development relating to the disease. I am kind of surprised how so many people are unaware what kind of disease this is and feel shocked to see this movie. Also people should avoid having too much cakes and alcohol at old age. Cakes and bakery uses baking powder that contains lots of aluminum can cause dementia and oligozoospermia, rather eat more apples or apple pectin that repairs neuron by increasing the brain derived neurotropic factor.

Title: THE FATHER

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: What an unbelievable performance by Anthony Hopkins.The Father is a proper experience - beyond sitting back and enjoying the movie - and it stays with you for hours, or even days after. The journey throughout that hour and half is as emotionally intense as anything I've seen.What a film.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: A dying man gets mental issues as aging. The only one he knows is his daughter. The shot of movie is quite confusing. It is hard for audiences to know which scene is real and which one is not. It is so confusing.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father is a good film with great performances and about the mind of a man suffering from dementia. It starts off like a typical father/daughter drama but as it progresses it takes a serious turn and we are left wondering what actually happened and was everything we witnessed just delusions?Anthony Hopkins is at his top of his game here, his performance is as good as Emmanuelle Riva in Amour which deals with a similar topic but depicted in a straight forward and unambiguous manner. The problem with The Father is not the concept but rather the presentation, the entire film feels like a play. Right from the production design to the dialogue, even the actors walk into the scene like its a performance stage.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: A devastating portrayal of Dementia told through a masterpiece of a film, where the audience is thrust into the mind of Sir Anthony Hopkins and gives you a truly unique experience of how it feels when your reality crumbles and changes every 5 minutes, you dont know what or who is real anymore, you lose your perception of time. We, the outsiders, in our ignorance, might get annoyed or angry at their hysterics but we dont know how their world is crashing down around them and they can just helplessly watch. Sir Anthony gives one of his career best performance, rivalling his Hannibal Lecter, and breaks our heart into million pieces. Olivia Colman is also superb as his daughter. The set design, editing, direction, music, cinematography all are top notch. A really important film for understanding Dementia and its Terrible Reality.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Florian Zeller's first job as director manages to move by capturing the story of Anthony, an old man being little by little consumed by dementia accompanied by the help of his daughter who does what she can in this vulnerable situation for both of them.First of all, the choice of how we see the film from Anthony's perspective makes it confusing at first for the viewer since it is not possible to differentiate the plane from reality, but when you realize that it is intentional it is a tool that you achieve. Empathize much more with the character and the pain is shared. It is a script that, as I said at the beginning, confuses but achieves emotions with the situation and with the main character, for my taste I prefer something more linear but I admit that it convinces and captivates.The color palette is magnificent, everything accompanies the scenes and vibes of the characters.Anthony Hopkins is not surprising, he is simply the acting beast that we are used to. Every time it generates more pain to see him and his face of not understanding and not knowing why, the final scene of him asking for his mother destroys you, 10 points.However, on the side of Olivia Colman I left much to be desired, I do not know if it was the expectations for what was said or that but her character did not reach me, I feel that I achieve emotions but not to the maximum, each scene that appeared a break for know more about her character, it was cut. I did not finish meeting that daughter with so much pain, I do not know if it was the script that failed to highlight her character or the linear interpretation of Colman that left me nothing but a neat performance.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This is the kind of movie which needs to be seen at least twice. Once in a lifetime one gets to see a performance so perfect. Anthony Hopkins plays a 84 year old man ( his real age) battling dementia , senility and a fading memory where he keeps forgetting names, faces, events and even timelines. His is a performance full of nuances, subtle, refined and memorable. When told by daughter Anne that she is leaving for Paris, Anthony ( also his name in the film) is bitter and says that rats are abandoning ship. He also keeps talking about his late younger daughter as if she was still alive. The film should relate to everyone since we have all seen old relatives with similar ailments.Director Florian Zeller skillfully uses different actors for same characters within the confines of the claustrophobic London flat. The director brings out the angst, distress, confusion and frustration of Anthony so effectively as he weaves the riveting narrative. It is a treat to watch Anthony as he cajoles his carer and does some tap dancing for her.The location of this film is the flat, and for immensely talented Anthony this is his stage where he delivers his lines with mastery. ( Luckily for audience the verbal communication of Anthony is perfect ). The most touching moment is towards the end when Anthony breaks down in a sort of catharsis as the carer comforts him. " I am losing all my leaves " he says sadly.The camera and characters do not move out of the flat. Only once the camera moves to the window to look outside and see a little boy playing and Anthony smiles. The film has excellent cinematography , editing and sound.

Title: THE FATHER

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
This is one of the hardest movie reviews I've ever had to write in my life.Mainly because of the films subject matter, Dementia.I've seen my own father succumb to this dreaded disease and it scares the hell out of my, worse than any horror movie I've watched.I sadly remember some of the last words my own father spoke to me were, "Be a good boy at School today."
I was 46 at the time.The beauty of "The Father" is how Director, Florian Zeller, takes you into this descent of losing your grip on reality through the eyes of the marvellous veteran and Academy Award wining actor, Sir Anthony Hopkins.At times his character Anthony is part Hannibal Lecter and at others a peaceful, but confused ageing Father to Olivia Colmans, Anne.Another Academy Award winner who puts in a highly believable performance as his daughter who's trying to deal with helping a man who refuses to accept assistance from her or carers.Fun Fact: Colman was named Anne is both roles she's been Oscar nominated for.Also great supporting roles form Mark Gatiss, Olivia Williams, Imogen Poots and Rufus Sewell.Overall "The Father" has been nominated for 6 Oscars, after already having over 20 wins in other awards and once you've seen this film you'll know why it deserves to win in Hollywood.At 83, Hopkins, is the oldest winner of a Best Male Actor BAFTA and a dark horse to scoop up the big one.This film feels like everything he has learnt in his craft is on display effortlessly for 97 minutes.It's hard to believe this is Zellers' feature film directorial debut, because it's a masterclass in cinema adapted from his own acclaimed play "Le Pere" from 2012.The role of Anthony was specifically written for Hopkins.One of the things that got the living legend to agree to this film apart from the top shelf script (adapted by Christopher Hampton) was the inclusion of one of Hopkins favourite pieces of music from Georges Bizet Opera "The Pearl Fishers".He's always dreamt of making a movie with this music in it.With lines from Anthony like: "I feel as if I'm losing all my leaves" "The Father" is so close to perfect I'm giving it 10 stars.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
The choice of jarring cuts and filming style hyped up the tension of a horrific film of the disintegration of a once keen mind
Hopkins is perfect in his magmatic performance
Just don't expect an uplifting ending with this type of story material.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Very experimental movie with Hopkins' phenomenal performance. Must-see for everyone.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The outstanding film by Florian Zeller brings vivid depiction of the ravages of dementia taking you to an unforgiving brutal journey seen through the sufferer's perspective...This remarkable cinematic art, profoundly performed and presented, will expose you to touching feelings and terrifying moments while staying relevant and truthful to the reality which is mysteriously blurred through the deceptions of the brain.A must see for all of those who enjoy a good masterpiece!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: If you have elderly relatives, or know anyone with dementia, then you will find this movie a terrifying watch. Having been in Anne's position myself I feel desperately for her character and I would have this movie firmly categorised in the horror category.Hopkins is absolutely at the top of his game and the script, sets, supporting cast and direction provide an exquisite but heart-breaking composition.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Poor Anthony. He is confused. Who's taken his watch, what's happened to his daughter, and where the hell is he? He is confused, but defiant. He refuses help. He insists he will outlive those who are plotting against him. If you know someone with dementia, or even if you don't, this film will ultimately make you feel sympathy for the one who has it yet does not realize it. It's like being in a hostage situation, while being stuck in a time warp. Such a person, like Anthony, may be irritating but is ultimately to be pitied. You wouldn't want to be in his shoes. "Nobody tells me anything," he declares. "I'm not an idiot," he insists. These are statements someone with the condition would typically make. Anthony Hopkins plays Anthony brilliantly, and he is well-supported by a competent cast. Go watch this movie, and leave with eyes opened.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Last movie I saw I liked of his was his supporting role in Meet Joe Black, he's acting just gets better with age... This time dealing with Dementia and questioning his every move, very well made and supporting actress Olivia Coleman, playing his loyal daughter... Very moving to watch... Cleverly made leaving the audience questioning what's real and feeling disoriented, a great movie!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Let me start off that this is my second viewing before I rate it..Of all the best movie nominees I kinda of watched this movie first with great expectations but it is just feels kind of a drag from my first watch so decided to give it another try after watching the rest of the nominee before coming back to this artsy movieMy review is this movie indeed is a tragic and is was shot in the actors perspective which is a newAnthony Hopkins was really great with Olivia Colman too, the scene where he switch from a good and funny conversation to a hostile and confrontational type of figure was mesmerisingAs well as the mummy scene was uncanny I really hope Anthony won for best actor in this category he is far more deserving that Chadwick Boseman..The things I don't really like about the movie is the pacing and the confusion that make me feels regarding which scene is real from imagination.. may be this is what the directors trying to achieveOf course this movie will not be the best picture I hope the academy won't disappoint me in the acting categoryIf it wasn't for Hopkins and Colman uncanny performance I would definitely rate this movie 5-6I am rating this higher purely on the acting not the story line.

Title: THE FATHER

Screenplay is put together so well. With all it's elements combined this movie has its own thing to bind the audience in it's own thrill and questions. Overall The Father is a movie which everyone will recommend others to watch. For some people it may fall in one time watch club and for others it will take position in multiple time watches.

Title: THE FATHER
