Old age is scary, and through his eyes and his incomparable performance there is no way not to get involved in this drama. On Google Play. #movieslover #googleplay #anthonyhopkins.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This film is a special reminder of how grand and extraordinary Anthony Hopkins is as an actor.I've seen many films that examines from different angles the subject of mental deterioration such as alzheimer's, but I think that this film portrays with harsh realism the essence of dementia, and how it can damage, hurt and torture a person on a daily basis. And how it can impact his surrounding. Florian Zeller combined his directorial skills and artistic vision with Ben Smithard' steady work of cinematography to bring the senses of confusion and ignorance to the viewer, so that we would feel gradually a pure and sincere connection with the main character. Putting Anthony Hopkins' performance aside, the whole cast from Olivia Colman to Rufus Sewell did a brilliant job.A truly fantastic work that deserves all its awards and nominations this year.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: What can I say? I just watched The father and I'm speechless. Anthony Hopkins is an acting genius. It doesn't matter. Silence of the lamb, Westworld, it don't matter, he always takes acting to another level. That Oscar was well deserved sir.Pairing him here with Olivia Coleman was like a match made in heaven. Every human should watch this movie.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I like it very much. It belongs to high-level works at the script and performance levels. Adapted from the stage play, the scene is more concentrated and single, but it can go deeper into the character's heart and create a strong sense of narrowness. The fragmented narrative not only enhances the sense of suspense, but also peels off the reality of the later life layer by layer, adding a heavy weight to the hearts of the audience. Although there are many films about Alzheimer's disease, there are few that can make the audience of all ages have such practical experience. From this level, this film should not only remember Hopkins's exquisite acting skills, but also applaud the humanistic care of this film. It is one of my biggest regrets in 2021 that the film group did not make the film and brought more viewers to see it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Hopkins' performance is an amazing piece of art. One of the best performances I have ever seen. The film is also really good, but if it wasn't, just watching Hopkins' performance would make it worth watching. Awesome, amazing acting.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: A realistic, touching yet terrifying, mind bending and absorbing film with great dialogues, amazing performances, settings and story.And Anthony rules!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This was the last movie I saw from the main Oscar categories and I was very surprised, I knew what the movie would be about but I wasn't expecting how the director would tackle it.It's a story about how dementia affects a relationship between a father and his daughter, but what makes it original is how we are presented the story, we see the movie as if we were in the mind of Anthony Hopkins and how scary the distortion of reality can be when you suffer from such an awful disease.It's both scary and fantastic in terms of how we the spectator have the chance to experience the downward journey of someone who starts to lose sense of what's around him.It has brilliant performances as you would expect and indeed I haven't seen Hopkins do such an amazing job for a long time, it was for sure one of the best performances of the Oscars this year, I would put it side to side with Boseman's but its definitely a class act!

Title: THE FATHER

Maybe Nomadland for best Actress, but that's it. Well, this is my opinion anyway. Enjoy the movie and respect all elderly people.

Title: THE FATHER

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Sir Anthony Hopkins, I applaud you." Who am I really? You're Anthony.I reckon my mom gave me that name, what a beautiful name."Character played by ANTHONY HOPKINS.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: An award-winning play is being made for the big screen - and by its director, who had no previous film experience. Can that work? Florian Zeller proves that it can. Dementia-stricken and proud Anthony learns from his daughter Anne that she will soon be moving to Paris. From then on, Zeller narrates the successive decline of Anthony's mind in complex but highly emotional and, above all, human ways.Anthony Hopkins is ideally cast for the lead role of Anthony. On the one hand, he is an empathetic father who means well for his daughter, but on the other, his pride and one-dimensionality make him sullen and critical of her decisions. Hopkins has never been seen in this simplicity. His character does not want to accept that his illness is getting the upper hand and is sure that he can manage without the help of care. At the same time, the increasing memory loss is told exclusively from his point of view, which automatically leads you to sympathise with the protagonist despite his often impossible deeds. This sympathy factor that Hopkins permanently carries with him makes it much easier to relate to him. It is arguably his best performance since his legendary one as Dr Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs, albeit much more nuanced and realistic. While the strong female role at his side then was Jodie Foster, this time it is Olivia Colman as Anthony's daughter Anne. She logically disagrees with her father and does everything possible to organise the help he needs before she leaves for Paris. Colman is the heart of the film. She is heartbreaking in this role and often cannot emotionally withstand the pain that the sight of her suffering father causes her. Her chemistry with Hopkins is also very deep and often one would think that the two actually share this kind of father-daughter relationship. Colman is fragile in her individual scenes, but also forcefully strong and always torn about her father's treatment. Rounding out the great cast are Imogen Poots, Rufus Sewell and Olivia Williams, all constantly taking on different roles due to the confusion in Anthony's head. Williams in particular adds an enormous amount of vulnerability to her few moments, especially the final scene.Zeller has succeeded in a very particular kind of filmmaking with The Father. In its simplicity, the film is nevertheless very complexly constructed, especially in the first hour, and one cannot believe that dementia can apparently really trigger this process in a person's head. Because Hopkins does such a fantastic job of translating this and the editing also relies very effectively on surprise and suddenness, it never becomes too much to bear. Zeller also manages not to make the film seem exclusively sad, but also enriches the plot with thoroughly funny interludes. Basically, however, The Father is a sentimental drama that continuously makes hearts beat faster and that you can hardly get through without shedding a tear. An instructive, authentic and fascinating piece of filmmaking that is an absolute hit for a directorial debut and should be seen by everyone despite the vehemence of its subject matter.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I usually won't watch films about this subject, due to real life. Our family has had to deal with a lot of dementia, genetically, and early onset. So I have avoided the subject for 60yrs.But quality films like this one are extremely difficult to find these days, and I figured Anthony Hopkins would be good for it (didn't know he won an Oscar for it, as I don't keep up with the mostly corrupt awards industry), so I had to give it a go. I was on the edge of my seat from the beginning, and stayed there until the very end. It is the most realistic portrayal of dementia I have ever seen. My dad is stuck on me being 35 (I am 68), so he's in a time machine not in his control. This film brought it very close, and helped me understand my dad's mind.I rarely give a film 10*, but this one is close to being perfect in every way.My favorite Hopkins film/performance is Remains of the Day. But this may be a new one, although much more difficult to re-watch. Hopkins is masterful here, as ever, but he's calling on all of his acting experience to deliver an effortless (seemingly!) performance. Nothing over the top, no melodrama, just one of the best crafted characters I've seen. He has help from a great script, direction, editing, sets, and co-stars, but the focus is Anthony. His character is as broad as it is deep, but so skilled is Hopkins that it seems effortless. I'm very grateful that Hopkins agreed to do this very difficult role, at his age. He could just sit on his laurels now.My age and health, as well as family members, begs many questions about aging and quality of life, which this film inherently, but without stating, highlights. I hope we can find ways for the mind to keep up with the longevity of our bodies, or provide for an acceptable alternative to warehousing our endless last days of confusion.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Not always a movie about dementia is so honest and objective from the patient's point of view as The Father. It's a simple and honest picture, we feel the pain from the both sides, the father and daughter.Hopkins' performance is just amazing, superb. It's a delight to watch him transform his character into pieces little by little. And on the opposite side we sense the painful journey Colman's character goes through.All the accolades go to the strong direction of Florian Zeller. We will probably hear his name many many times from now on.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
I think all elements of this movie is very greatly gathered and match to eachother, Anthony Hopkins is perfect!! After watching this movie I knew that why he won academy reward for this movie.At the end of movie I was cried when he said
"I feel as if I'm...I feel as if I'm losing all my leaves(😔😭)"
I think think everybody who has father should wathch this movie...
at the first part of movie I thought that "Anthony" is really healthyaand his daughter want catch his house or sth like that... I said with myself "it's a repetitive movie!!"
but after a while it was more & more attractive than before and really thrilled me to watch it to the end! And now not only I'm not regretful about watch that but also, definitely I was losing a gem if I don't!!About the structure of movie,I think the director makes some perfect loops in some part of movie to show us repetitious life or illusions of Anthony's life. But despite I think this a very very perfect thing but caused that the movie lose its coherence in some parts and it's really confusing!!Anyway I love this movie!!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: One of the highlights of his remarkable career, likely one of his best ever perfomances. Bravo. Film is great, but it's all about acting. Olivia is decent as always.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: 2 great actors, great directing, masterful movie as the rendition of last chapter of human journey slowly end. It's like sitting on calm yet poignant Dusk, beautiful yet sad because we know the Night will finally come.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: From birth the mind grows wise. Accumulating knowledge. It shares its bounty throughout life. It stays sharp and expands with every emotion a human can express. Then, when Its least expected, the colors fade. Images blur and blend. Memories travel on multiple tracks with no certain destination. Uncontrolled, thoughts entwine and imagination explodes into a new reality. Or is it? This film is a must see. A must feel. Hopkins is quite possibly the greatest actor alive today. Experience his character! Absorb him. He is us tomorrow. Or the day after.....

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: A very difficult and painful movie to watch about real life. Anthony Hopkins' best performance by far since Silence of the Lambs.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I can't believe I just awarded one star to a film with substantial roles for Olivia Colman and Rufus Sewell, two of my favourite actors.Hopkins just drags it down ... and down ... to the point where it become totally predictable and utterly unwatchable.Hopkins is, in my opinion, an insanely overrated actor. He had his best moment 30 years ago in "The Silence of the Lambs" and never quite showed anything new since then. In fact, it seems as if he has regressed to his pre-Lechter mediocrity. His last turn, in "The Two Popes," was another totally forgettable appearance.The writing for his character offers him no chance to break-out of an endless loop of confusing daughters, chickens, husbands, and that damned, perpetually-missing wristwatch.Would he have received an Oscar nomination in a non-pandemic year when the release of fresh films had not been so drastically truncated?There is some solace that Academy Award for Best Actor will most certainly go to the well-deserving Chadwick Boseman, a great talent taken from us all too soon.Hopefully this will be the last we see of 83-year-old Hopkins. Even Laurence Olivier, an actor with a far, far greater range, had the good sense to retire, returning to the screen for a final three-minute cameo appearance in the year of his death at age 82 in the non-speaking role of a wheelchair-bound World War I soldier (his voice, reciting a poem, is overdubbed).The director is to be faulted as well. Just as with "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom," "Father" began its life as a stage-play set mostly in one room, to be performed for live audiences of about 1.000. In both cases, nothing was done to open up the story, and they do not meet the criteria of film: they are but documents of stage dramas, complete with five-minute monologues which would work well onstage, but not in film. But if I need to hear someone rant for five minutes, I'd much rather it be Viola Davis.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Hopkins delivers a performance of a lifetime- nuanced, graceful, elegant and emotionally overwhelming. I have seldomly emphasized this much with a character on screen. Simply thinking about certain moments bring up a distressing feeling inside my body and mind. Hopkins vulnerable acting is masterfully transported onto the viewer, he is the core of the film, this is by all means his film.But lest we forget the expertly crafted direction of Florian Zeller who constantly shakes us up with the disorienting unfolding and modification of events. He doesn't deceive us by inserting distasteful pathetic music choices but rather uses music only when it is really warranted and doesn't take anything from the performances away. Thus a healthy co-existence is created and the film doesn't feel emotionally manipulative.As I said, this is a devastating film whose overall nature lingers with you long after the credits roll. A film which makes you remember why cinema is often called an "empathy machine". It is because of films like these.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This is a slow and sad film . A lot of it takes place in an apartment. It is based on a play . Anthony Hopkins puts in a brilliant performance as the elderly man Antony suffering dementia . Olivia Coleman puts in a good performance as his daughter .

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This is the best acted, presented and directed movie I have seen in ages. All the actors involved were superb, especially Hopkins of course.When the movie finished, and still now, it had me thinking about my own life and relationships a lot.I would recommend this movie to anyone, and would happily watch it again. It made me cry, especially that heart-wrenching ending!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Finally! A decent and perfect movie after waiting for quite a while. I didn't expect any quality lately, in past several years, almost all produced movies have been below the average. Especially Academy award nominees and winners have been the worst in most of the cases. So, This one surprised me big time. Great scenario, amazing story telling, superb acting and perfect directing. You see the world as an Alzheimer patient sees it and it gets terrifying. I haven't ever terrified this much by watching a movie before. This one is a sad terrifying story that could happen to you and your loved ones in a very realistic view and by a considerable probability.It is decidedly the best movie that has been produced in last 4-5 years. But the academy awards as always( at least it has been the case lately) failed to do its job. It is a shame that this movie did not win the best picture.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This film is a joke sir Anthony Hopkins is a rich person living the high life flat. Well that's not the people I live with my mum had a stroke and rich people can address it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: So this is a study in dementia. It left me feeling like I had dementia because I spent 137 watching a flick whose narrative was revealed within the first 10 minutes and then did not really go anywhere particularly interesting, after that.If it wasn't for the actors and in particular Hopkins' performance, I would not have bothered, Florian Zeller/Christopher Hampton or not!!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This movie should be BANNED and ERASED from the history of movies. I couldn't take it. It was sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo slooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooow. Every line was like a knife that just cut deeper into me.The entire time I kept hoping for a twist... something... ANYTHING... to actually happen. I knew that Anthony was sick from the very beginning - that was pretty obvious. But I can't believe that's all there was to it though. No twist. No surprise. No nothing. Obviously not even a happy ending. He's sick. That's the whole story. Goodbye.Every other line is "What do you mean?". Not even kidding you. I seriously doubt that whoever wrote this script has ever spent even 5 minutes with someone who has dementia or Alzheimer's. If someone is sick and you know they're sick and they start talking about something that clearly doesn't make sense you don't ask them "What do you mean" every 3 seconds and then act surprised that they don't remember what you told them 2 days ago - THEY ARE SICK! HELLO??The director clearly thought "Maybe if I slow this down to a painfully slow pace they'll think it's a masterpiece!"10 minutes of this movie was someone doing stuff in the kitchen that had nothing to do with the story.This was first written as a book and then adapted to be a play in a theater where you have just one or two locations and they never bothered to adapt it for film. It all just happens in that one apartment. As soon as I saw in the credits that it was based on a book I knew I'd be wasting my time. But I thought - let me see what all the fuss is about.Believe me when I say this - I put more effort into writing this review than the writer of this movie when he wrote the script.AVOID AT ALL COSTS!!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: What else should I say? This movie is flawless . Anthony Hopkin's acting in this movie is impeccable and one of the best of his career !! The ending is so touching and sad .

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father draws you in, and through a )initially confusing) plot device tries, mostly successfully, to immerse the audience inside the experience of the father, flawlessly played by Hopkins, and magnificently acted all round . The films stage origins are clear, but the overall effect remains heart rending and deeply affecting.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The kind of unexpected perfection you get when you combine Anthony Hopkins, Olivia Coleman, British filmmaking, and a very low budget of just six million dollars.Watch, join dad in his mind, try to make sense of what is happening, where you are... who you are.Watch true artists at work, in front of and behind the camera. A Masterpiece. A tour de force.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I think I've got dementia now that I've watched this it left me very confused and irritable. Great acting by Anthony hopkins and Olivia conman. It was very sad but sometimes funny. Well worth the watch.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This movie confuses the heck out of you and you can't really figure out what it's supposed to be about until it's almost over. So in theory you should watch it once to get an idea of what it's about then watch it again to appreciate the fine acting. The only problem is that it's not interesting enough to watch twice. Sure, there may be some great acting performances but great acting does not a great movie make. Somebody could play the perfect performance as Hamlet, for instance, but if he's playing to an audience that doesn't like Shakespeare nobody is going to care how great his performance is. And that's the problem with The Father. A lot of people will go to see it just based on the name of the stars but most of them won't want to stick around to figure out what it was supposed to be about. My wife's mother had Dementia and her brother cared for her by himself and eventually with a carer for years before she died, so they might empathize with it. People who haven't experienced that will just see a confusing mess.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Heartbreaking and haunting, a perfect portrait of dementia as the mind slips away memories fade and are replaced with hallucinations and paranoia and once a perfect gentleman is reduced to the state of infancy , his only remaining daughter is no longer able to care for him and he is sent to a nursing home . But that is not all to it , with proper care and in hands of professional and kind medical staff he too is able to find comfort and peace of mind in hands and embrace of them , so that his remaining days are peaceful. Having dealt with a granny who suffered from dementia this movie's portrayal of sickness as accurate and informative, kindness and patience are the most important thing to keep in mind when dealing with people with dementia and maybe perhaps professional help is required.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: An amazing film for a first feature. A brutal subject that has been a theme in several movies, but this one goes deeper allowing us to see from a different point of view. Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman never disappoint, both gave astonishing performances.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: It's a must for every single one who was out of touch with reality at least once. Frankly speaking, this movie touches upon lots of different social issues such as distrust of your own relatives, chronic mental diseases and also misunderstanding between people. Having watching that, a viewer could think thoroughly about mutual support and self-belief. This was a triumphal performance of Olivia Colman and Sir Anthony Hopkins! Don't hesitate to watch and enjoy this movie - it's definitely worth a shot!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Truly amazing story and the performances were all excellent. One of the best films I've seen in a while. It really puts the viewer into the story in a way not many other films can. Hopkins was incredible as usual and Colman, OMG....what an amazing actor.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: As good as this was, what was missing for me was an acknowledgement that what we're seeing is advanced dementia, and particularly severe at that - someone who is not just frightened, confused and forgetful, but paranoid, aggressive and suspicious. The film perfectly captures what the final 6 weeks with my dad were like before he went into care, and how he often continued to behave while in care. It also conveys how frightening a large aggressive man with dementia can be to those trying to care for him, as well as the terror of alienation when a loved one with dementia turns against you. As a couple of other reviewers have commented, most of the characters don't handle the man's condition well and act in ways that make him more agitated - the fact that even experienced care professionals are shown repeatedly asking him "What do you mean?" and "Do you remember?", and being surprised that he forgets things even when his condition is clearly severe, simply isn't realistic and is used to artificially drive the point home. There's no sense that his family and carers have acclimatised to the situation and learned to modify their behavior, when in fact that's one of the first things that happens when you have a loved one with dementia.Because the film is designed as an immersive experience from the perspective of someone highly agitated with severe dementia, what's missing are all the moments of joy and love in between. There's no recognition in the film that many people have much gentler manifestations of dementia, and can live for years with dementia with a good quality of life. This film will terrify people and generate huge fear around dementia, and I really want to emphasise that although many psychological and behavioral aspects ring true, it represents an extreme scenario (one more reminiscent of Lewy Body dementia than Alzheimer's) and that having dementia doesn't have to be like this. I know people with dementia who still actively pursue and enjoy their hobbies and who have put all kinds of practical coping strategies in place (either independently or with their family's support) to ensure they can carry out their daily activities safely. I know people who have had dementia for many years, whose short-term memory is completely shot and who are reliant on others for help with certain tasks, but who can still cook, garden, read, do puzzles, follow politics and current affairs, engage with friends and family, and generally take an interest in the world - and who enjoy their day almost every day. That's what dementia can be too, and what it is for many, not just an unremitting horror show. Please don't think it has to be this bad, at least not all the time.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father is carried by Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman. This movie is told from Hopkins' perspective, as he ages his memory fades and things get more confusing. This movie was emotionally powerful, beautiful, and sad. While the point of this movie was to confuse us, and put us in Hopkins' shoes, I still got a little lost. I felt like there should have been a little more explanation or at least a little bit more of a sense of what was really going on. Nevertheless, the performances are fantastic. Anthony Hopkins is amazing, best I've seen him in years.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Exploring a diseased mind of a demented being is hard to watch, harder to act out. Anthony Hopkins deserves the Oscar for a difficult role of an octogenarian afflicted by Alzymer. Coming soon after his unforgettable Pope in Two Popes, he establishes himself in the pantheon of Cinema's Greats if that was at all doubted.A disturbing story with confusing overlaps of the demented mind is nightmarish for observers more so than for the sufferer.Olivia Colman is superb in a restrained role of the daughter who suffers the sufferer.Background score is noteworthy.A worthy nominee or awardee for the Best Picture.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father doesn't really have a story. There's no place and time. Not really. "Real" being the key word. What is real? When, where? Who? Anthony, played by Anthony Hopkins, who rightfully won an Oscar for it, is real. He's the titular Father - a retired engineer suffering from dementia. His daughter Anne (wonderful Olivia Coleman) is also real. His son-in-law (Rufus Sewell)? Probably. But when? And what about the home care aide named Laura (Imogen Poots), who reminded Anthony of his other daughter Lucy?The most striking thing about The Father is that the narrative is driven by Anthony's point of view. To him it's all real. But familiar people and places morph into unfamiliar, reality blurs with dreams, and he is desperately trying tether himself to at least the time with his trusty watch, but he keeps misplacing it. Or rather mis-hiding. Because the only way this nonsense can be explained is that everyone is out to get him and his stuff. He's suspicious, angry, and abusive towards his loving, heartbroken daughter. And the moments of clarity are even more devastating as fear of abandonment sets in - unavoidable, blameless, and real.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: "The Father" is adapted from director Florian Zeller's stage play by the same name. It is lead by Sir Anthony Hopkins, who delivers a mindblowing Oscar-worthy performance. He acts as an aging man, who slowly loses the sense of reality due to dementia.The audience doesn't know what is reality and is as confused as Anthony. Director disorients us by having different actors play the same characters and even the set keeps changing. We hear different versions of Anthony's life, and we even seem to experience events out of order.This movie is a tear-jerker and a unique piece of art because it focuses on the feeling and not the truth of the experience.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Everyone is mentioning Anthony Hopkins and rightfully so, he did an amazing job here, something you may not be used to this days. But I also want to take a moment to thanks all others who worked on this movie. Everything is all so cleverly put together you forget everything else around you and totally get captivated by the story. It just shows how you really don't need a huge budget to make a really good movie (well I'm guessing 90% of the budget is for the 5 actors).Ps. Fun fact about Paris: they don't even speak english in there.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Wow just wowFor me one of the greatest films of all timeThis breaks down the myths of Alzheimer's disease and educates the viewer on what the afflicted, and their loved ones are experiencingAnthony Hopkins fully deserves his oscar he received for this and Olivia Coleman also deserves oneThought provoking, gut wrenching and an absolute tear jerkerThis should be required viewing for all care workers who really do deserve to be paid like rockstars.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This really surprised me. Rather more than just about a family trying to care for the needs of a loved one with dementia, it really goes some way to offer some idea about what that could be like for some people. It's actually quite a difficult movie to watch, remarkably draining, in it's approach. I don't want to say too much more, would only serve to spoil it, though the trailer gives some idea about it's approach in this regard.It would be interesting to watch again, in that I'll know what I'm in for, but going in somewhat blind, as I did the first time, I found it strangely unsettling! Nothing horrible in it, there's just something about it...I would be surprised if it doesn't do very well at the Oscars, in one way or another.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony Hopkins gives an amazing performance, one of the best in his career, is hard to decide who deserve more the best actor between him and Chadwick Boseman, i know is controversial, but i would vote for Hopkins.Olivia Colman also gives a great performance, showing all the sadness a person would feel in this situation, but Hopkins is the one who elevated the whole material.The ending scene is very emotional and sad, showing once again how amazing is Hopkins performance, when he cries asking for his mother who is obviously dead a long time ago, this just shows even deeper how much he's lost in the time of his own life, the scene also make us see that a person in his condition can feel like a helpless kid who lived a entire life and now is completely lost and confused, sometimes not even capable to remember who he actually is.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: THE FATHER is one of the most powerful films in recent memory, with two knockout performances from Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman. Hopkins plays an old man who is plagued by dementia, and who is refusing care from his daughter, played by Colman, because he believes that he can take care of himself adequately on his own. The movie is structured from the perspective of Hopkins -- the audience often sees things in a non-linear fashion and is not introduced to certain major characters, making them just as strange to us as they are to Hopkins in his mind.The writing from Florian Zeller is impeccable, managing to be creative while also giving us a devastating look into how it feels to suffer from dementia. While it sometimes feels just as much like a play as a movie, it never bores the audience with any superfluous details and implores the audience to attempt to find their way through a maze that has no ending. The editing and direction makes us feel as though we are being deceived, making us empathize with Hopkins while also siding with his caretaker, who is doing everything she can to care for her sick father.The performances are the best of 2020, with Hopkins being possibly the best he has been on-screen in decades. (If Chadwick Boseman weren't such a strong contender for lead actor, I'd say give the Oscar to Hopkins.) Colman, however, may be my pick for best supporting actress, because she portrays the pain of watching a loved one slip into confusion and paranoia with heartbreaking reality.The final ten minutes of the movie are my favorite scenes acting-wise of the past year. THE FATHER is an essential watch that everyone should seek out.A

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
If you liked:
Nebraska
Amour
Relic"The Father" is one of the 2021 Oscar frontrunners, a heartbreaking drama about aging. An old man named Anthony is refusing help from his daughter as he ages. They are at a point when the child is worried enough about their parent to try to get them a professional carer; and the parent, fighting for the last bits of their independence, is proud enough to insistently believe that they can perfectly manage on their own. A terribly awkward situation for both to find themselves in and although we sort of side with Anthony in the beginning; we eventually do see that his mind starts to slowly disintegrate and fragment, starting with simple forgetfulness, and ending up with a nasty habit of believing that everyone is out there to steal from him.What makes this movie so unique and borderline genius is that we see the whole story from Anthony's perspective only. He is clearly showing early signs of dementia; and we only get the side of the picture that he himself recognizes and sees through his confused memory and eyes; to the point where we ourselves become paranoid and confused. The faces are confusing, the time of the day is confusing, the surroundings are confusing. Because of that, the film isn't constructed like a dull drama, but rather as a some twisted kind of mystery thriller bordering on horror. Probably most of us have at least once contemplated on our own mortality and the paralyzing fear of losing one's memory as we become older. This film is not scary-horror, but it should scare the stuffing out of anyone, since this problem is universal for all of us humans. The prospect of getting lost in your own head is far scarier and far more real than anything some Boogeyman from a generic horror film can throw at us. It's what I have been afraid of ever since I could think hard enough. It's also one of the reasons why I became a biologist, I am planning to delve into Biology of Aging research so that we can live healthier lives as we get older, and avoid this kind of horror in our lives and the lives of our loved ones.All of this was brought to life by the never-changing excellency of my favorite actor Anthony Hopkins, rightly earning Hopkins his 6th nomination; and the superb directing of Florian Zeller, for which he confusingly wasn't nominated, but his film did get the "mysterious" Film Editing nomination for all those cuts that made the confusion of a fading mind tangible.This brutally real film won't provide you with any answers, but it will give you a ton of questions to ponder on. Comparatively very short, running for 90 minutes only, it is definitely one of the best films of 2020 that nobody should miss. Available in some theaters.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Shining a spotlight on a deeply upsetting subject but telling it's story in a way we can empathise with all parties involved. THE FATHER is devastating in it's deliverance, Anthony Hopkins is incredible in his performance, dementia is truly awful and this film has left me totally broken.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Who else but Sir Anthony Hopkins could portray the lead in this sad story of a man with dementia and the different worlds he sees and lives in. Very sad and by the end of the film all you want to do is hug him and tell him things are ok.It hits the right note for anyone who doesn't understand Dementia. Cracking movie!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This movie is hard to watch, In a good way. This utterly realistic depiction of a man losing his mind is one that goes to really emotional depths. All of the movie's emotion is expressed through Hopkin's acting and a screenplay that shows its premise through the writing. This movie is told in mostly first person, and that at times causes scenes to have shockingly horrific moments in the idea of a man's mind attacking him. You as an audience cannot follow the events of the movie without having to piece nuggets of information that other characters mention. Be ready for heartbreaking scenes that make you want to reach out and save our main character. Bring tissues.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I think this is what they say, twinning between director and the actor.No offence! But Anthony's age and the character is matched in a perfect way and the experience he gives us while watching, makes us think about senile father what he goes through.Grateful to the director and actor, giving a different perspective.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This film has a simple story just following a man with dementia and how the people around him are affected by it. The acting and screenplay is what makes this film and this showed with the Oscar wins. Hopkins plays a simple character suffering with dementia and captures the struggle he has when people don't believe what he sees with his illness. Production was great as well. I was able to stay engaged even with the film being in one setting (mostly). Do watch this film, some may be able to relate to the story as well.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: A very emotional film, after watching you start thinking about life. The main strength of the film is Anthony Hopkins' distinctive acting. Honored Oscar!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I really wanted to see this film and deliberately didn't read any reviews or watch the trailers because of this. I think the plot is fairly simple and nothing is being given away with the synopsis of how it describes the characters demise into dementia.As an explanation of the condition its great, but as a film it doesn't really work. It does a very good job of describing the descent of the main character, and gives a fairly vivid description of his confusion, despair and random behaviour, but this becomes quite tiresome and repetitive as the film progresses.There just isn't enough of a story here, nothing of significance happens, and even when changes occur to the character or his circumstances, they happen within the disconnected framework of his condition which is a very low key, subtle affair.There are no developments that take place to draw you into the story, the characters plight, or that of his family. The screenplay in general is very one dimensional and offers no real emotional investment in the film, other than pity of his condition to progress past this fairly slight and unrewarding concept.Don't get me wrong, I'm sure many people can identify with the film and even realise with so much more understanding how dementia affects people (especially loved ones) because of this film. It highlights the effects of the condition exceptionally well. I'm also sure older people watching this will probably have an unpleasant experience on what's possibly awaiting them in the short to medium term, but as a movie it still doesn't work, it isn't enough. It is more of a documentary, as a movie it simply doesn't deliver.I'm struggling to give it a fair score for movie value whilst recognising the intent of the film makers may not have been specifically entertain per se, and I'm finding it quite difficult. What the film does, it does very well, but outside that it has little to offer, and I think as a result 5/10 is a fair score.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Excellent script, seamless narration, and life-brimming performances!That being said, I would add, people should watch the movie: Android Kunjappan Ver 5.25 (2019)

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
That's what cinema was used to be like. In teh good ole days. This is more than film, it's a masterpiece. I don't know how it came to be and I don't even want to know. Let it remain a little mystery. But I'm glad it did.Not sure if I can even try to give this a score - it's very unlike anything in past say 5 years. So I have nothing as a gauge.Let's say 8.5/10 exactly. And this is my Academy Award winner all around (review is being posted pre ceremony). <---- Came back minutes later to adjust this to 9.5
9.5! I'm kind of scared of how long will the aftershocks last now.PS. I somewhat disliked Olivia Coleman since her Peep Show days purely for her looks (yes, I was that shallow) and probably biased by her character in the same. Years gone by, staggering performances delivered, but I was still 'iffy' about her (imho!). After The Father I've changed my mind finally. She's an amazing actress and a wonderfully beautiful human being.Third edit here. This is an addendum. Come to think of it during the watch I was vaguely reminded for some reason of a film called Locke. And then I remembered that Olivia was in it as well. Huh. Thing is - Locke IS kind of a gauge for The Father. Or the vise versa now? The only one that came to mind. Hmm.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Brilliant acting, taut writing and deft direction; this should be the benchmark for all films. Anthony Hopkins never lets up as an actor, he puts everything he has into each and every performance and refuses to sink to the pedestrian levels that actors like Travolta, Willis, Cage (except for "Pig"), Brosnan and many others do in the later years of their careers. The Father is a treat.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony Hopkins breathes Cinema and Pure Acting in this.What an emotive mvie . I am not afraid to say that the ending brought me to tears. For sure a magnific performance, what a well deserved Oscar.This man will never be forgotten, he will be immortalised as one of the Best.Hopkins turns a Great film into a Masterpiece to be studied!!!!!!!!!!!!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: A tremendous movie that accurately portrays how life is for dementia sufferers.The movie shows the audience someone with the onset of dementia, struggling to determine what is true and what is not, confusion and reality sometimes colliding and the viewer, like the character, really not knowing what is real and what is not.This movie takes the viewer to a place unfortunately many will see either as a victim of dementia or a son/daughter or carer of those with dementia, it is a journey sadly many will make.I believe this movie will help many understand the frightening world our loved ones are in and hopefully we will be more understanding for those that have it and those that care for them.Anthony Hopkins is deserving of an Oscar for his performance.Highly recommended.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: If Hopkins hadn't reached immortality for his acting already, his latest artistic achievement would have owned him this status even once more. He gives a nuanced powerhouse performance of an old man loosing his connection to reality, to his relations, and at last to his own identity, caused by dementia.It goes totally under your skin and leaves you in tears.The fact that you see the action from Hopkins point of view gives you a disturbing and sometimes even frightening impression of what you might have to expect suffering from dementia yourself.Hopkins is accompanied by the wonderful Olivia Coleman, both playing a wide range of emotions between tenderness, rage, fear, sadness and humour.Those two save the script and the movie from being a bit too tricky sometimes, if those tricks wouldn't work all so well.Brilliant!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Dementia is an awful disorder, and it's every child's nightmare to have to watch their parent deteriorate and disappear right before their eyes. Florian Zeller manages to capture this experience magnificently here in this film adaptation of the play Le Père which he co-wrote with fellow playwright Christopher Hampton.Anthony Hopkins is everything in this film - funny, charming and also utterly heart-breaking - he completely deserves his Oscar win after putting in what will surely be remembered as one of his all time great performances. The way we enter his seemingly coherent mind and reality only to watch it gradually unravel until he is left as a broken man unsure of his own existence is stunning. Praise also has to be reserved for Olivia Colman who has to portray the daughter having to watch her father go through this nightmare. Some of her best work is done when she is not speaking, but instead letting her face do the talking. She could have easily won a second Oscar for her role here.The original score from Ludovico Einaudi is also great (but I love everything that man does) and I liked the use of the set design to illustrate the subtle differences in the constantly shifting and changing reality we inhabit for those 97 minutes.The entire screening was completely stunned into silence as the credits started rolling, as everyone was trying to come to terms with what we had just seen. This may prove to be one of the finest film experiences I'll have this year.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: A Brutal, Trippy Portrait Of Reality - Showff, An Oscar-Worthy Performance By Anthony Hopkins. This Movie All About, A Haunting and Devastating View of Dementia.. Just Watch This Heart Wreanching Masterpiece'

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This movie broke my heart about a thousand times, and quite frankly in the beginning/first half: I thought I was losing my mind. What is scarier is that this is a real possibility for me. As I get older, I worry about it more and more. Genetically, we thought my paternal grandmother had Alzheimer's (when it was first being recognized). Then, my father "had the cardiovascular system of an 80yo" in his 40s. Blamed cigarettes. Fast forward to when I was 40yo. A neurologist told me I had a problem that is only found in 80yo people or "is there something genetic to this?" Well. I've been terrified since.Now, what these people SHOULD have done was have photos of his daughters/wife around him AND a current calendar. This helps so much (till they become really out of control and think everyone is conspiring, but not many places mass produce calendars for the future with all sorts of information on them). Even then, you can reason with them to a point. My grandmother was so much better with 100 calendars, and we kept old ones with photos of her (and grandpa) together: A calendar from 1925 accompanied by photos of her, gramps and my father as a baby. Just a tip to try to help anyone reading this. You'll do anything to spare them this if you can.Ok, the movie, I'm sorry: Excellent and devastating. The acting was wonderful, and I'm glad they didn't have a huge cast. Two Olivias playing Anns. Truly a heartbreaking movie and I cried more than once. And to add to the sadness, you have to see everyone else's point of view. The struggling daughter, the impatient husband, the young caregiver trying to be the good girl which mingled more with his mind...it was a rough ride. But I do NOT regret watching it. I'm going to suggest my children and grandchildren watch it as well.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The only flaw I can find to this movie is that is too sad and poignant, to the point that by the end it had me sobbing like a little girl. It's the kind of movie I wouldn't be willing to watch a second time. In a fair world, I can't see how any other movie would stand a chance at winning the Academy Awards or any actor other than Anthony Hopkins (at 83!) at winning Best Leading Actor, but sadly, we all know how things operate this days...

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: It has been a long time since I have seen a movie with this caliber. The acting is truly superb with each of the actors and actresses. The way "reality" is depicted for a person descending into the depths of dementia is frighteningly accurate. Everything was executed beautifully. I believe that it is extremely important for everyone in the healthcare industry, for family, friends, church, and community members to see this. As one who is assisting in the care of a loved one with dementia, it is so very important to be patient and also to not show a surprised expression to common odd behaviors or comments, which can alarm and shame the one who is ill. They need our love, attention, and assurance. Do not hesitate to see this!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Heartbreak and confusion are two ideas and themes I've encountered before in my life. But never before have I seen it so brutally abused in The Father. The Father doesn't just tell a story about the character Anthony and his scenario, rather it places us into the mind of Anthony and his mental deterioration, showing us the heartbreak that is experienced by the ones around him and the confusion and even acceptance of his own situation. At one point, Anthony' consciousness fully acknowledges that he is a burden to his family members in a dramatic, and devastating scene. It's unsettling and sad, and the films depiction of caring for a loved one with dementia is what we possibly may experience later in our lives, even now. And it's this idea of empathy through the audience and fictional characters that Florian Zeller communicates through the film with his heartfelt and unbearable narrative.I happened to catch this in theatres today, as it's my first time back since a year now. I never realized how much a luxury the theaters are and the impression it could make on an individuals connection to a film. For some reason, the fact that I was watching the movie in a theatre rather then in a living room felt more impactful to the nature of the story. Again that idea of empathy, the closeness with the characters I witnessed through gazing at the big screen. I give credit to this from the cinematography and camerawork, writing, and especially the acting from Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman. What largely made an impact on me was this film's transitory depiction of home. The people we rely on to define us may suddenly seem unrecognizable, and that's just disturbing. But I think Zeller's use of empathy also provides us with an alternative effect of comfort on the viewers.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The way this film is edited is incredible, putting the viewer in the shoes of a person suffering dementia with the confusing time jumps and inconsistencies within the stories chronology. It's hard to grasp on what's going on, but that's the point as that's how it connects you with the character. Anthony Hopkins also gave an incredible performance which attaches the viewer to this struggling old man. He made me feel all the emotions of his character, it's simply beautiful. It really deserves acclaim for being so original in its approach to storytelling by making the audience feel like they're experiencing the characters life rather than just observing it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Those who have or have had close experiences with relatives who suffer from senile dementia or Alzheimer's will find in this film a very moving story. For those who do not, they could also fall into the sensitivity presented by the masterful role of Anthony Hopkins.However, when the story is already set, it could be a little bit slow and predictable.Nominated for 6 Oscars, including Best Actor and Best Picture, "The Father" bears some resemblance to another great film, "Still Alice" (2014) starring the great and only Julianne Moore, who actually won the Oscar that year for best actress.Highly recommended.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Was not expecting that I did not stop guessing who was the baddie. Give that man an Oscar.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The highest point of acting is when you don't see the actor, you see the character. For the entire runtime of The Father, I only see the main character, the father, instead of Anthony Hopkins.The movie stars only about 10 people. It sort of creates an illusion that there are a lot of actors. But no, they're the same people.Illusion. A great way to describe The Father. It's very confusing at times, but you eventually find out that the whole film is in the father's perspective. It's a brilliant way of directing and also writing, which is done by Florian Zeller.All actors have done great job. Namely Olivia Colman and Imogen Poots, a surprisingly good actress if you don't count Black Christmas. Sir Anthony Hopkins did such a perfect job that you are in his character.This movie is acting, directing and writing at their greatest. It is a boring drama for some immature moviegoers, but people who have a brain will appreciate this a lot.The Father tells an emotional and heartbreaking story, and it's one hell of an example of brilliant filmmaking, it will forever have a special place in my heart.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This falls under the category of "exceptional movies I never want to watch again". A painfully accurate depiction of a man suffering from the progression of dementia and the effect on those around him. Hopkins is phenomenal. One of his greatest performances. And one of the best movies I have seen in a long time.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I just wanna thank to film's team for showed us how hard it is to our oldmen who is in like that condition. Thank you. Very sad & touching but it is a SAD which we need to understand in real life. Thank you.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Remember you must die and the old age is inevitable.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: If you have any experience or personal history with dementia in your life, I would highly recommend skipping this one. Not because it is a bad movie, the opposite actually. The movie would probably hit so close to home that, even for me, it will be a bit too much to handle at times. This is one of the most realistic movies I have ever seen. Even tho I have never experienced anything in a form of dementia in my life, I could feel the realism and tragedy that is going on. Anthony Hopkins gives one of (if not the) greatest performance of his career. He nails every aspect of his character. From the big memory loss moment to the subtle little movements, everything has meaning and consequences. I would also highly recommend watching it twice. The first time you will experience the movie with the main character and try to puzzle everything together. The second viewing you will appreciate the story a lot more. There are a lot of little moments and sequences that make the story even more complete. Some scenes go on for a bit to long, but it all works out at the end. It didn't hit me as hard as I thought it would at the end, but it still left me with an appreciation for dementia and everyone who has been in contact with this horrible disease.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Such intriguing, moving, stressful way of showing this conditioning I appreciate it so much, having family members living with it, is appreciated Beautiful filmmaking amazing performance such a talented cast.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The father is a masterpiece. Period. If black comunity is angry because the Academy doesn't give the Oscar to Chadwick Boseman is because Antonhy Hopkins' performance on this film is just superb. Sorry. Boseman doesn't deserve an Oscar for a just right performance. If you can't deal with that, sorry. In a scale of 1 to 10, Boseman has a 6 or 6.5. Hopkins is beyond 10. This is the lifetime performance on which every actor would like to arrive in his silver years.The film is about an old man who starts to lose control of his mind, and what mr. Hopkins delivers is just impressive. Not only the world of confussion, regression, and halucinations, but the very frailty of human condition are portrayed with supreme craftmanship, but with a big understanding of what all these means in the eyes of the surrounding familiars and the spectator. The most oustanding feature on Hopkins displayed is the absolute dignity and humanity of his character. The most impressive thing about the film is the slow crescendo on which Anthony (Anthony Hopkins) is involved, which ends with that astonishing monologue on which he claims for her mother. I can say that that is one of the most incredible scenes I have ever seen in my entire life. I almost burst in tears when look the absolute loniless and frailty of his character. I came back to this at the end of mi review.Is an impreessive accomplishment from one of the most relevant actors of the last half century. Doesn't deserve that performance the highest acknowledge from the Academy? That's what what's happened in the 2021 Academy ceremony. Few awards reward such oustanding performance, and that's hasn't to be with racial issues but with a supreme actoral craftmanship.Nevertheless, I have to say that The Father barely rose the real ordeal on which patient and family members have to get through on this illness. BTW, senil dementia is not anymore an accepted term in psychiatry, because normalize something that is not normal. Instead, modern psychatry suggest Brain damage with 3 levels: minimun, medium and great or severe brain damage, since not all the ancients suffer from this. Other thing on which the film fails is in the treatment to release the patient from this condition on hallucinations, confusion and mental regressions. That's not cure or relief with pills but with haloperidol, wich stabilizes the brain and help the patient to avoid suffer from this symptoms. It's so obvious that the film doesn't want to deeper on this condition, instead it suggest the part on wich all involved in this condition suffers. In that, Anthony Hopkin's performance is absolute devastating. The film accomplish in show us how frailty is our humanity and the suffering both the patient and the family, portraying both with such respect and human dignity that very few films attempt.By personal experience, my mother recently has that kind of episodes, everyone is a truly nightmare with a length from ten to 16 hours on wich my mother and us, her family, were driven, I can say that the film doesn't explore that nightmerish experience. The final scene on which Hopkins cry for her mommy is an exactly portrarit of the ordeal on which my mother was driven by this illness, and is absolutely devastanting, one of the most impressive and painfully scenes I have ever watched.Never an actor has deserved more an award that the 2021 Oscar for mr. Anthony Hopkins. There is no point of comparison between his performance and that of the late mr. Chadwick Boseman. Just can't be compared. It's not a racial issue, but an artistic all in all, and in that field, mr. Hopkings delivers his most impressive performance. A masterclass in acting. Best male (or female) acting of the XXI century by far. Period.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: My mother suffered from dementia for her final years. The outsider looking into her life, her behaviour, would have seen something like what this movie portrays. What sets this film apart, of course, is that we never -- not ever -- could know what was going on inside my mother's head, while the film imagines it brilliantly.At first, it seemed as if this would be *just another* cinematic effort to deal with this awful illness, and there have been so many. But I don't remember any one of them triggering such empathy. Wow. And full marks too, to all carers, whether within the family or professionals. Really a very, very moving film experience.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Yes, if you ever thought he couldn't top his turn as Lecter, here it is. One of the best masterpieces I've ever witnessed.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony Hopkins has always shown how great an actor he is in this film his portrayal of a man suffering dementia is very moving and I couldn't help feeling how I imagine that's what it is like. How things appear to change one minute to the next He deserves an Oscar for getting it just right not over stated not about him it really was a good storyline doubt he will get an Oscar the Oscars will be going to whoever. But if you want to see the best portrayal of what dementia is like this is the film. Not sympathetic, not about the other.people who are suffering in coming to terms with it although there are brilliant moments where the Father can make such put downs. It's a must see film. Simple as that.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
Apart from great acting of the cast I didn't liked anything else from this film..
.Well it's my personal opinion
Story didn't worked out well for me
Screenplay same
At the end I was left completely disappointed.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: If you know someone with dementia or it runs in your family, you must see this film. Truly a masterpiece and an amazing glimpse into this terrible disease. Don't believe the bad reviews. They know not what they write.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Such touching story and movie went to cinema to see this so some bits our funny but u can tell how the father is suffering from brain trauma and u can tell he can see things at end of the movie he said he wants he mum back and he's daughter back who died in car accident so sad.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: You really legend hopkins great acting indeed,,,,,,, despite that it is 1:37 but i felt like it was more and more i enjoy it and i will change my vision for people which has that kind of ill.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
This masterpiece movie is a Poem for humanity Talk about our common feeling like fear about to be alone and lost our family memebers , And this movie is suggested common for all of people with all culture in the world , not like majority of useless movies in hollywood like woke and majorty of lgbt or useless blockbusters movies.And I cry a lot at last.one of the best feeling Ive ever
experienced.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Wow that was so hard to watch for me. I was raised by my father after my mom died when I was 3. He is 80 now and starting to have memories problems after his stroke 4 years ago. He is a different man now. Anthony Hopkins is so amazing, such a brilliant actor. I love him in everything he does but this is now my favorite. Everyone was great. It took a bit to get catch on the the same few days were being plaid over and over but once I did then my mind started putting things together. What a nightmare I hope I never get dementia and I hope my father doesn't either. Be prepared to ugly cry, I couldn't breath out of my nose for half an hour after I watched it.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Great performance by Anthony Hopkins! Just thinking about this characters suffering was awful.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Sad movie! If you think about it this is a possible nightmare we could all face!!!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I have a grandmother with alzheimer who no longer recognizes me, one day I am my father, the other my grandfather, the next an unknown person, but although I always try to understand what she is thinking, we will always analyze the situation with our own eyes. And this is what makes this film incredible, for being able, in an impeccable way, to show us what my grandmother's life is like through her eyes.Everyone should watch this film, especially those who have someone with the same diagnosis in the family.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Anthony Hopkins really delivered an incredible performance. Sad and touching movie.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I hope she will come and see me sometime. Do you think ? Mommy.You were saying she might come occasionally at the weekend. My mommy.(Start to cry) I want my mommy. I want get out of here. Have,have someone come and fetch me. No,no,I want my mommy. I want her to come and fetch me. I want to go home. I feel as if I am losing all my leaves. The branches and the wind and the rain. I do not know what is happening anymore. Do you know what is happening? All this business about the flat. I have nowhere to put my head down anymore. But I know my Watch is on my wrist, thatI do know. For the journey. If not,I do not know if I will be ready to ...------- The father.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: No Oscar is worthy of Anthony Hopkins performance here. One of the World's best actors of all time just raised the bar to a height that I can't see being bettered anytime soon. Olivia Colman's performance is utterly superb. This is not the type of film I would watch. My wife suggested we give it a try. At the end, we were both speechless and in awe of the best film we have seen in many, many years. I felt is if I was living in the story, as if I were there, in his shoes, in their shoes. I highly recommend this film. The story may not be for everyone, but the acting by Hopkins & Colman is as convincing and real as it can ever get.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: If you are scared of dying or growing old you're going to be very moved by this. If you're very empathetic toward others you're also going to be very moved. If like me, you're a perhaps little more emotionally cold, and watch drama with a sense of detachment, then you're not going to be moved but you will see some very good acting from Anthony Hopkins.This should work for me. Hopkins has always reminded me of my father and my father faced some mental decline toward the end. Parts of it are quite good but what lets it down for me is the script. I know it's an award winning play but so many of the characters around 'The Father' talk to him in unrealistic ways. What they say is not totally unbelievable, but it's not natural either. Even though he's been in decline for a while they all seem surprised every time he forgets something. If you've dealt with this sort of thing, even once, you roll with it. You explain what you need to explain, what you think will get through, and you move on. You don't act all surprised that a man who's losing his memory has forgotten something again.It's somewhat off-putting and serves to remind you that the playwright is making a point rather than an observation.I get that it's mostly from his point of view, but with better direction the actors could have played it with a more realistic world-weariness that comes from dealing with this stuff every day, without seeming like they were trying to explain and reveal things to the audience.It's still a good film and should hold most people's attention to the end. Those who get caught up in the story may miss the obvious clues on the 'twists', but it's not a film where the plot really matters. It's more about creating a sense of empathy. And based on that, and the fact that that aspect of the film failed for me, I can only rate it 5. Which is not to say it's good or bad. It's a solid film. It just didn't personally connect with me.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Heartbreaking, and doesn't feel like a movie. Terrifying, really.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The final scene is utterly heartbreaking and incredibly played by both actors. This felt like a stage play on screen to me and there isn't a step out of place from a single character or performance. That final scene will stay with me for some time.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: The Father is entrancing. It will keep you bewildered throughout, as Anthony Hopkins flashes his acting prowess. He keeps getting better with age. This movie is eerie and too real.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I think this might be a film I remember for a long time. The Father is a film that will slowly, emotionally collapse you from the beginning to end. It really makes you feel like you're inside the mind of someone with dementia, and it's truly heartbreaking. In many ways you could compare The Father to a psychological thriller.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I am 67 so this was a tough watch. It is brilliantly acted and the script masterful. Where did reality start and dementia takeover? Makes you realise that for some it is gonna be a hard path.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: What a performance by Anthony Hopkins , really a brilliant actor this performance made me terrified that when i will be old i will be like him every moment I got more attached to this story , i really liked this movie very much and i think i will watch it again just for pleasure.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
Fantastic movie.According to my girlfriend who works for so many years with people with dementia, this is as close as it can get...
Beautiful! Worth 2 Oscars.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: We see the movie in the father eyes or if I sure from his memories , it's take you in deferent level , Anthony Hopkins take us to his mind to nowhere , and when the movie finsh you sit and think abote future when you need your mammy , lose your leaves and your self , then no one can helps you !!!!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This movie touched me on many levels , first of all , the acting was great , the directing and story telling , however my admire for this movie is for personal reasons, my grandma passed away 2 months before this was released , and she had Alzheimer, she had the exact same symptoms , she always remembered her dead child , and asked to be moved back to her mom house , but only now I understood what she faced an what she went through , the fear and the isolation , the distraction and the fuzziness in every single thing , I cried a lot while I'm watching for everything that i did wrong cause I did not understand , and now i can see and feel, hope everyone who is in touch with a patient to see this masterpiece and try to learn from it .

Title: THE FATHER
Comments:
It is very hard to write about this movie because i can´t really describe how great it is, it captures feelings so well what a great performance Olivia Colman and Anthony Hopkins.And let´s not even talk about the film editing so great
this deserves more recognizition i´m very surprised and angry that the academy didn´t nominate Florian Zeller for best director, it´s his first film but it feels like he has directed over 30 films.Simply amazing.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Going into this I was expecting an hour and a half of some painful emotional scenes of dementia from the perspective of the daughter. Instead I was taken by surprise at the ingenious decision to immerse us in the perspective of Anthony himself. We see things from his perspective, which wasn't just more insightful, it also allowed the movie to become one giant mystery. The story wasn't just emotional, but it was suspenseful and filled with plot twists that make you watch until the end. In fact, the plot was so layered that it almost requires a rewatch. I compare this a lot to Christopher Nolan's memento except is not in reverse and not as violent. Personal favorite awards season movie. Underrated!!!

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Damn. I had this in my queue to watch with my mom and aunt, both in their 70s, when we went on vacation. But then I realized that maybe it would be too difficult for them to watch so I watched on my ownAt 53, this movie will have a lasting impression on me that I in no way expected.Amazing acting by all actors. I've probably seen all of Anthony Hopkins' movies and this might perhaps be one of his best performances. Hard to tell though- he's such an amazing actor in everything.Poignant, haunting, brilliantly honest.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This film was one of the most raw and most real movies I have watched. It tells the story of one of the worst diseases humanity faces in such a gut-wrenching way, staying away from the sometimes unnecessary and drawn out melodrama that film tends to produce. What makes this film so beautiful is the fact that we experience the film through Anthony's perspective (save a scene or two). Though Anthony is the being that suffers from the illness, we are there with him. We feel the confusion and the desperation for fulfillment. We crave answers to the questions that are posed to us through Anthony's eyes. He wants to know who he is, what he's doing, and what's going on around him, and we want the same. In this way, Anthony's experiences become ours. We see what he sees, and we feel what he feels.Something I want to make note of is the film's setting, which takes place mainly in a few flats. The sets are all complicated - there are numerous doorways, a clutter of furniture, and several different rooms. The disorganized set is so carefully designed to mimic Anthony's mental space. Just like parts of his brain are hard for him to access, it is hard for us to assuredly recognize the characteristics of the flats and to easily notice the switching between them. This is all excluding one single part of each flat: the doorway at the end of the hall. The way that the camera always steadily follows Anthony in and out of that room highlights the inevitable truth of the situation... As Anthony continues to rely on the solitude that the room at the end of the hall offers him, the eery shots of it force us into reckoning with the uncomfortable truth that Anthony won't be able to escape to it forever. Though the film chose not to display Anthony's eventual death, we all know that it's soon to come. Instead, the film shows one last heartbreaking moment where Anthony cries for his mother, stripping his mind and being into the likes of a child's.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I hoped for this movie to get in different directions except the obvious one.I thought about a conspiracy / ghost / going in circles - but not the boring nothing that was this movie until the very end.All the good reviews are given solely because Anthony Hopkins is playing the main character in this movie. Replace him in your mind with a regular actor, not a very acclaimed movie actor and you get the boring nothing.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Colman and Hopkins are absolutely brilliant! What a great movie, well deserved Oscar wins. Also, one of the most depressing movie I've seen, because it is so real, the situation, the emotions of everyone involved, the dark side of aging, the fragility of life....all so real. Will touch many hearts, especially of those with aging parents.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: This is a powerful film.Sir Anthony Hopkins is not in it.There is a man, old then getting older, who finally disappears. He knows that he is gone. With wringing hands, he asks who he is. He is terribly confused and afraid of being abandoned. I wanted to hold him, to kiss away his tears. What could I do to help?In 1965, The Who released an album called "My Generation." The lyrics include "Hope I die before I get old."In this film, Sir Anthony is the epitome of Alzheimer's.In this film, Sir Anthony is extraordinary.I hope Sir Anthony receives the academy award.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Technically, The Father is well made, with good quality direction, cinematography, editing and sets. But the script, acting and general atmosphere left me cold. Already too long at 1 hour 37 minutes, this movie is the cinematic equivalent of falling into depression over several hours (it actually feels like centuries). One of the UK's most over-rated actors, Anthony Hopkins, executes his lines with his usual hallmark 'character' and aplomb, but was operating in an empathy-free zone and I felt strangely unmoved by his plight. The other actors take a workaday approach to the job, but all those middle-class English accents prattling on froze my brain, and I missed a lot of their lines because I was yawning (my jaw still aches). This movie is unattractive, uninspiring, tedious, annoying, and life-draining.But it did make me feel something: it made me feel depressed about the prospect of getting old, and the growing probability we all have of getting dementia. Having relatives with dementia is bad enough, but watching someone's mind dissolve in front of your eyes for entertainment must be appealing only to people with a sick sense of humour or disturbed morality. Hope I die before I get old. Or at least before I ever have to watch this movie again.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: If you want to know what it's like to have dementia or want to know what it's like to care for someone who has it, then you found the right movie. I don't think I really needed this movie, though, because I kinda figured that's what it would be like. The performances are good but I'm not sure why this needed to be a film, except to get more people to see it. I feel like it would have been more powerful and meaningful to see the play. It left me pretty flat, like the screen it played on.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: Before there was "Iris" and " Amour". Two fantastic movies about Dementia/illness.Then there was that horrible candycoated film called "Still Alice" which was like a Hallmark TV movie. Dreadful and Julianne Moore should have that Oscar taken away for that mess.Now we have "The Father". My fellow reviewers have painstakingly dissected it's wondrous attributes. So all I will say is 'Watch It.' Just a damn good film. Thank you ,Sir Anthony. Watching your performance is pure joy and pathos. Hold that Oscar high.This film should be on the List of 1000 movies to see before dying.Put the kids to bed, don't have snacks or alcoholic beverages. Turn your phones off. Savour this.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: I watched this with an open mind as I wasn't sure what to expect. The movie at the start played almost like a psychological thriller with character changes to unsettle you. Subtle changes of the scene with each shot and a real deja vu on conversations are then made to disorient and confuse you and put you into the shoes of Anthony Hopkins' character. It works very well indeed and near the end you don't know if you're coming or going. The last 5 minutes are overwhelmingly sad and hits home the subject matter of the film. From reading some of the low rating reviews it is clear these people have no clue what is a good film. Unless it's The Fast and the Furious or a no brainer action movie, it will be boring and confusing to them. To others who have a modicum of intelligence, an appreciation for good filmmaking and an understanding of the subject matter, this will be an absolutely outstanding gem with a strong resonating beat that cuts straight to the heart of you. Such is the utter emotional devastation this movie fills you with at the end, to watch it again would be painful. Hopkins deserves his Oscar for this without doubt.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: What a performance!. Anthony Hopkins told all the young actors to sit down with this performance . They will be showing this in theater and acting schools for a long time.

Title: THE FATHER
Comments: My sister-in-law and I chose this for our first post-lockdown cinema visit. Both of us have experience of having cared for parents with dementia, although that is not why we chose to see it: indeed, we struggled for a while making up our minds whether it would be wise to watch a movie that had great potential to be triggering. Given the option, we'd probably have chosen something more cheerful! In the end, our decision to watch it came down to the fact that we knew it was a well-regarded piece, and nothing else on our local picture house bill held any appeal at all.I'm glad we saw it.
